reviewText:
I've been playing Killing Floor for years and it is without a doubt one of my favourite games here.

+ The combat and carnage is unparalleled: explosions, dismemberment, and headshots look and sound great
+ The class and perk system is incredibly robust: classes have unique roles, pros/cons, levelling is addictive
+ Huge variety of weapons and maps adds a ton of replayability
+ Best free seasonal updates of any game out there

Fair warning, this is a skill-based game and it is difficult. Newcomers should start on Normal difficulty to learn the ropes and have fun. Playing on Suicidal and Hell On Earth requires a lot of experience, working as a team, and in-depth knowledge of game mechanics. For many people however - myself included - this is the real draw of the game. If you put in the time, playing on HoE with 5 other experienced players all working together is some of the most fun you can have online. There is also nothing more exhilarating than being the last one alive on Wave 10 knowing your entire team is watching and relying on you to stay alive.

Highly recommended.

reviewText: In my 40 years of video game experience I feel Killing Floor is one of the best FPS games ever made.\nThe depth of the game is great.  As much as the game focuses on multiplayer  and teamwork and the game shines in those respects.. the solo side of the game is perfectly balanced to make it a great experience also.\nAs you progress in difficulty the money gets less and it becomes harder to make sure you have the weapons you need when you need them, but as you progress in level your weapons become cheaper and more powerful.  The enemy is varied and as you get in higher difficulties you need to develop the tactics to take the tough ones down safely.  Many tactical skills can  be employed beyond defending one area and who is best suited to kill what depending on choice of class.  Situational tactics like target priority and when to run and how to kite"

reviewText:
Don't usually comment or write reviews, but when a game is this old and still brings out free content u have to give them credit, in today's sad monetized gaming industry of Season passes, online passes, launch day dlc, early access, etc.

I got into KF pretty late, around couple yrs ago. The first 5 mins I thought this is the biggest pile of crap I've ever purchased. Graphics are ugly, wave after wave in the same smallish map?!?! Why on earth are ppl still playing this game? I put it in my trash list.

The following day I had a strange urge to try it again, for whatever reason I don't know. I soon realised this game is not about arcadey run n shoot n regen health bs. This game's depth is about u as a team player and improving yr skills to take on bosses and tight situations. Reading the danger signs, when to run when to hold ground. You won't suddenly level up and get a powerful weapon, u only progress with improving yr gameplay.

The weapon mechanics are simply amazing. WARNING: after playing with no aim cursor and using only ironsights all other cursor games will suck.

Then there is the community made content. More guns, maps, zeds, bosses.....I have over 1500hrs entertainment time and I only paid $5. I think I bought some dlc just to support devs but its not enough for what they've achieved. I don't usually buy newly released games, the ones I've bought I've regret. But when KF2 comes out....just take my money, take it. Please.

TLDR: Buy the game. There's not many devs that care about their product.

reviewText: After playing a total of 126 hrs, I could honestly say this is my favorite zombie FPS style game. The game is incredibly fun and takes strategy to master, especially when attempting to play on the Hell on Earth difficulty. New weapons and free maps come out frequently which help keep the game interesting but being charged to own the latest and greatest weapon packs can be a bit of bummer.. Like all zombie based games, it tends to become repetitious. Luckily, having the option to increase the difficulty, play objective modes, and strive for seasonal achievements gives players more challenges/options to keep the interest in playing alive.  If I had to rate the game, I would rate it a 9.5/10. Would bang.

reviewText:
The best zombie shooter ever made. Teamplay here really is key, either play together  or die alone in a very very horrible maner.

Its wave based with stronger enemies spawning each wave and concludes with a final boss wave. Weapons are perk based and perks can be leveled persistently trough playing. Perks help with lowering weapon costs, higher damage and that sort of ♥♥♥♥. Weapons are purchasable with money gathered trough each wave (by killing, healing, welding doors, assisting kills...). This combination is what I believe make the game feel great.

Most of the DLC are skins and only offer cosmetic changes. The community weapon packs add more weapons (although you can do without). I should also note that the developers still support this game trough frequent free map updates.

reviewText:
Brief summary:
Pros:
+Easy to jump into and have fun
+Should be able to run on the majority of Computers
+Huge amounts of replayability
+Workshop support ensures you can always try a new map or mutator out
The game's harder difficulties provide a real challenge to the hardcore
Most of the DLC is purely cosmetic
+The game is frequently updated with newer weapons (This might not happen anymore
as kf2 comes closer)
+Has a SDK if you want to use that.

Cons:
Some of the perks you can use aren't as useful as others
The hitboxes can become a pain at times
Some mechanics aren't explained at all
At times, the community can be bad(They're a minority)
Recent DLCs lock some more useful weapons away. Not too big of an issue though
Server browser is a bit annoying at times

//Long version//

Killing floor is co operative first person shooter where up to six british men can exterminate zeds,an experiment gone wrong.(There are are also a few women and a robot)


Graphics: Killing floor's graphics are decent and the art style of some maps in particular are amazing, and give out its atmosphere well. Don't expect anything spectacular though.

This game should be able to run on most older pcs just fine if you lower the graphics a lot and your resolution. Any good pc should run this with no worries.

This game caters to both casual and hardcore players. The objective is simple, kill all the enemies. It's easy to jump in and understand that you should probably kill all the guys trying to rip you apart. for those who play the game more often, the game can get really intense on the harder difficulties, where an understanding of each zeds mechanics is required to succeed.

Since this is a team based game, having friends along can make the experience much more better. Although if you're a solo player like me, the game is still a ton of fun, just a lot more fun with friends. Every enemy in this game feels unique, from the basic waddling clot to that guy with a chainsaw for an arm. Each enemy acts differently, and each have characteristics that separate them from the others.

The maps in this game are of a wide variety. Some take place in urban environments, some in factories, others in fictional lands. With the workshop, you can find countless more community maps.

The voice acting of this game is both a positive and a negative. It is humorous at first, but when you start playing a lot, it gets incredibly repetitive.

The majority of the DLC for this game is cosmetic, skins for your character or a camo for you weapon. There are a few DLCs which give you new weapons. none of them are completely overpowered but some contain useful weapons. I recommend buying these DLCs first.

At its price, killing floor is absolutely worth it. It also frequently goes on sale, so grab it during then if
you're unsure.

// Review end //

reviewText: I don't know where to start as a long time player. Killing Floor is sickness, a wicked one at its finest. Teamworking wave by wave your way up to face the horror itself is a great fun. Although, game itself is coated in black humor, which is swirled inside small popular culture and steampunk references. Not everyone's cup of tea at that, but I assure you everyone can take the joy of killing mindless clone armies even it's given in a literature covered in vain and desperation.\nGame is hard, I'll give you that and it takes time to get used to some patterns, but once you get used to it; they will become habits like the game itself. More you play, more you will seek about its balance and mechanics and it will sink you deeper into it. Because getting better and everything resolves in teamplay.\nIf you're into black humor, survival co-op, hidden popular culture references and mindless killing fest where you are the actual prey; you gotta buy this game and play it. Otherwise, keep playing your tacticool and deathmatch first-person shooters.

reviewText:
Killing Floor is a casual, story-driven game. It's a creative interpretation of current day America and deals with controversial issues such as immigrants, gun control and abortion. Similarly to the Bible, Killing Floor can be interpreted literally or figuratively at any time, depending on whatever point you want to prove. Putting this in the genre of Surivival/Horror is risky as one of the perks removes any sensation of danger or difficulty. This simulator accurately depicts areas like suburbs and packed metropolitan areas in a utopian society. The constant thrill was incredible - something not expected from a turn-based rpg.

From looking at the landscape to watching people die right before your eyes, any casual player should take a swing at this team-driven, racing game.

I give this real-time strategy game 10/10.

reviewText:
Killing Floor - ReviewKilling Floor is a teambased first person shooter game made by Tripwire Interactive that puts an emphasis on teamwork. The main goal of the game is to work together with a team to kill a certain amount of zeds in each wave in order to get to wave 11 and kill the patriarch. Without working together with your team and forming a plan of some kind, you will die. That's one of the best things about Killing Floor, and one of the reasons why I love it so much. However this doesnt mean it's without its flaws.

There are 7 perks aka classes to choose from and they each play a specific role in your team. You'll level up after doing enough damage, getting headshots or killing a certain number of zeds. The higher you level up, the more benefits you recieve such as lower weapon costs and a starting weapon. However this isn't necessarily a good thing since it puts a big gap between newer players and the long time players. The perks themselves seperate Killing Floor from a bunch of other games since each one plays differently.

Guns are a plenty in Killing Floor with around 7 or so weapons per perk (more with dlc). Each perk weapon is special with the amount of damage it does, how fast it shoots, and the reload speed. Each weapon also has a different sound effect which really gives each weapon a unique feeling to them as well as making some weapons really statisfying to kill zeds with. This doesn't mean that all weapons are good though, some are unbalanced and are either too costly for it's own good, or not being better than some of the higher end guns. The berzerker perk however doesn't feel as fleshed out as the others since you're basically slapping the zeds while trying not to get hit.

Along with the many different guns, maps, and perks this game offers, there's also many different zed types. In total there are 10 different zed types including the patriarch and each of them behaves differently. Because of this, some perks and the weapons they use work well against certain zeds, another thing that makes Killing Floor one of my favorites. However, this requires you to memorize different strategies to use for each of the zeds resulting in a slightly difficult learning curve for newer players. Although memorizing the paterns comes naturally to some people since the behaviors correlate with the sound cues they give, so it isn't too big an issue.

Overall, if you're looking for a challenging fps game, you should definitely give this game a try. While Killing Floor 2 is already out and similar, the original Killing Floor feels like a different game entirely with different strategies than the second game. If you know anyone who plays Killing Floor, you should play with them as playing with friends makes this game much more enjoyable. You can usually find this game for $5 during sales, or you can get it in the Digital Deluxe version of Killing Floor 2, but it suffers from a ton of bugs that ruin Killing Floor 2 (Microtransaction drops are bugged despite already being  such a controversial feature, gg tripwire).

Pros:► 7 perks / class to choose from
► Tons of weapons and maps
► Weapons sound great and each kill is satisfying
► Difficulty and zed count ramps up as more people join (teamwork is essential)
► A nice and fitting soundtrack
► Multiple types of zeds that behave differently
► Hilarious british accents

Cons:► Unbalanced Weapons
► Melee isn't fleshed out as it could've been (fitting pun)
► There is an objective mode, but it only includes 3 official maps (you can however find some on the workshop)

Hit / Miss:► Learning curve requires you to memorized what works against each zed, which might ward off newer players
► Somewhat slow start

Personal Rating:Avoid at all costs
Pick up during a sale
Worth Playing
Must Play

reviewText:
After playing the Killing Floor series for over 700 hours I personally believe I've achieved the right to give my personal views and thoughts on the series itself.

This review will also have my completely terrible and obnoxious reasons on why Killing Floor deserves my meaningless score.

I think it's safe to say that the British Wannabees at Tripwire Interactive do not give 2 actual ♥♥♥♥♥ about graphics and specs hence why the recommended specs are alot lower than the average specs of other popular games on Steam. This game however has graphics that are a steaming pile of ♥♥♥♥ with repeatitive gameplay as well and with voice acting so bad that it's almost so ♥♥♥♥ing good. Though Killing Floor does have list of flaws consideribly longer than David Cameron's ♥♥♥♥♥ and completely irrelivant speeches, this game has achieved such a massive fanbase just enough to keep it flooded with screenshots, mods, artwork, friendly fans and videos.

So how did Killing Floor become so successful you ask? It's a really good question but simple to answer, this game is possibly one of the most clever games ever created due to the fact it's not one of the games where you try to get the other side of the level and re-stock on supplies then trying to get to the other side of that level or trying to gather supplies and making gangs and being a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ruining other people's experience with that game. On the FLIPSID3, there are games which grind a new game nearly every year which shoves loads of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in your face than there are fanboys on majorly popular games such as Team Fortress 2.

Now I'll be on about the gameplay of Killing Floor, for obvious reasons you can see how this series can get really repeatitive quickly but it seems to draw you in each time when you load it up even after it's gone past to the extent of being new and different. There is loads of hope and joy in the game when you finally destroy the Patriarch on a Hell on Earth 6 Man match to the time when you find yourself trying to clutch the last actual non-boss wave as a Medic with 3 Fleshpounds attempting to slap your sexy ♥♥♥ is still absolutely fun I suppose it goes towards to this mystical sense of spirits or something congratulating you making you want to play more long after most games which would surpass their enjoyment points. Killing Floor's true achievement gameplay wise goes towards to the creative minds of the community, you can play on maps made entirely of cakes and sweets to using custom weapons such as RPGs to ♥♥♥♥ up Fleshpounds and trash zeds in anyday of the week.

One thing I'd love to say before I close this fustercluck of a ♥♥♥♥♥ review is that what really makes Killing Floor stand out in the Zombie/Survival games arena has just got to go to the community. I've got to say this again, the amount of custom maps,weapons,skins,community made zeds is absolutely brilliant and big props go towards Tripwire Interactive taking in feedback and developing Killing Floor where it is today is absolutely phenomenal.

But the distinctive lack of foxes makes me mad so I'll give this game a 1/10.

Actually Killing Floor is a phenomenal series so I'll give it 9/10.

reviewText:
Adrenalive-fueled & addictive // Recommended for those looking for quick tempo & gratuitous carnage
+ Leveling system is basic but well-implemented, as are the class perks
+ There is a frequently implemented slow-motion ability which, when triggered by a player, affects everyone; rather than proving a nuisance, it surprisingly adds to the experience & makes for some very cinematic moments (also does well you give one a few quick breathers in-between the action)
+ Soundtrack is heavy & loud; perfect for the pace of the game, & serves to get the player's blood pumping
+ Very helpful & generous community; this is most often demonstrated by the culture of money dropping & weapon sharing that is extremely prevalient (almost uniformly) among the player base
+ Voiced quips are comical & entertaining
+ Intensely satisfying gunplay & general combat; weapons, even melee, feel as though they have weight
+ Vast arsenal of weaponry to choose from
+ Steam workshop integration; very mod-friendly, which serves to increase replayability with a little bit of effort
+ Impressive enemy mob variation, each with its own, unique characteristics

- The amount of in-game advertising, either for DLC or products completely divorced from the title, is very distracting
- Declining population; at the time of this review, there were a number of servers available, & several of them were full up, so it certainly isn't a dead game, but it was noticeably less active than when I first picked up the game a year or so ago
- Poor movement animations & sub-par textures; presentation is a bit strained by age, though not jarringly so

LockeProposal's Big Day Out

reviewText:
About this game:
Killing Floor is a Co-op Survival Horror FPS set in the devastated cities and countryside of England after a series of cloning experiments for the military goes horribly wrong. You and your friends are members of the military dropped into these locations with a simple mission: Survive long enough to cleanse the area of the failed experiments!

Features:
This game features some hilarious physics, excellent gore and violent gameplays. There are also seasonal events where the game's Zeds will be changed/updated to a holiday themed monster. In addition to that, there are achievements that is only obtainable during a specific season/event.

Recommendation:
It is advised to play this game with good friends before jumping into public online servers. Because this is a co-op survival based game, teamwork is critical to surviving. One would always meet people that will refuse cooperation due to the human nature of the online community. Always select servers with PINGS under 260. Any online game with over 260 becomes extremely difficult and sometimes even rendering it being unplayable. There will always be people kind enough to show new players the ropes to becoming more experienced/better with this game. So what are you waiting for? GET THIS GAME AND PLAY!

reviewText:
Excellent co-op game that benefits from good enemy design and varied and high quality map selection. The gunplay feels right and I think it benefits from no artificial crosshair. The heavy emphasis on good smart teamplay to survive further serves to improve the experience.

To survive a wave of failed abominations (well are these ever really successful?) after a visceral bout where one mistake might well mean a full belly for these monsters imparts a definite sensation of achievement. The perks system works well and once your skill level improves along with your preferred perk’s level you’ll be able to tackle the harder difficulty levels that are truly “hellish” for the unprepared.

Simple design, excellent execution and a tense game that rewards smart teamplay makes for an overall excellent online experience that only improves with friends.

reviewText:
A damned good zombie-killin' co-op game if I've ever seen one. Seven years after its release and this game is still going strong. The gameplay is solid and well-balanced; every class and every weapon has a place in the game. Leveling up can be a pain but it's ultimately worth it.

The people in KF tend to be a bit smarter than the typical co-op player; I've hardly seen any trolls in-game and most people at least make an attempt to play well. My only warning is to be careful of what servers you play on. I've been immediately banned from games for poor or nonexistent reasons. Laughably, the admins of KF servers tend to be worse-tempered than the players. Don't be suprised if you get booted from a game. As usual, playing with friends and / or playing on a server you can trust helps a lot.

Also the sound the Trenchgun makes still makes me inexplicably happy.

reviewText: Tripwire Interactives Killing Floor is what you would expect of a polished mod, but doesn't exceed expectations as a retail game. It's good, but unfortunately far from perfect. A nice addition to the survival-horror genre though, and it has an attractively cheap price tag.Once a mod now a game on its own, Killing Floor confronts the player with hordes of undead minions threatening his character’s life. While being independent enough of zombie-shooter-king Left 4 Dead with features like sealing doors, character perks and weapon stores, the game itself offers little variety and a flawed AI.It's not the sort of game that future generations will gather to celebrate, linking hands and singing sad songs of fond remembrance. It is, however, clever, boisterous, faintly silly and relatively cheap.Hectic coop multiplayer game offers no story but straight–forward nonstop mayhem in stylish locations. Rich and balanced equipment makes the multiplayer clashes all the fun.Ultimately though, the sort of plotless killing gets old, or at least it did for me.A decent little title, and a testament to just how far you can take your hobby if you but try.

reviewText:
The Short: Get it if you want an old school FPS that's co-op based. Old game engine, no story really to care of, good gun mechanics, hard learning curve relative to modern FPS's (COD MW, Battlefield); balanced game play, rewards skill over earned perks/guns.

The Long:
It's kind of weird to have a game with really a rubbish, tissue thin premise and graphics from a decade ealier to have anything really to offer in this COD MW era of FPS.  On a whim and a steam sale, I bought KF just for kicks.
By the looks of it I have the guns, the companions and a dumb AI to deal with, this should be a cake walk for an hour or so, and then I'm back to Far Cry 3/BD...well, Far Cry is crying in its lonely corner with Michael Biehn for a while now.... What KF lacks in graphic polish and writing, it has in game balance, this is  where the classes are complimentary towards each other, every shot counts when things get thick and there are no gun/bomb/airstrike/gunship to save you. If you're not playing to the strengths of your class, your team mates will and do yell viciously at you. The real satisfaction is when you play with a good team and beating up the baddies :3
Even if you find that it's getting easy to survive then just crank up to Hell on Earth, and you'll find out how old school FPS Killing Floor will drag down your ego. There also is a huge modding community given KF's relative small player pool against the likes of COD and Battlefield. I did play the Halos, COD MW 1+2+BO and BF 2 for extensive amounts of time on Xbox, but this is a good alternative and reminds me of my Unreal 2/UT days :3

reviewText:
Let's see here..
A fan of FPS ?
A fan of shooting and decapitating zombie heads ?

As you can see from my hours, what I find is that the community (or friends that you gained from people you met from public games) is the one that makes this old game worth the time. While there are normal solo and objective mode along with mods, the real value comes from multiplayers as this game's main value is through co-op.

This game have 5 difficulties:
Beginner (Every zeds drop like flies if you hit them enough)
Normal (A bit more challenge, needs slightly more coordination between teams, but spam and pray method still works)
Hard (A more difficult challenge, needs better coordination between teams, spam and pray method is not so effective anymore, even level 6s can die pretty quick in hard)

Why do I stop here? Because the last two difficulties will be discussed later. Now... for first-timers...

You start out knowing nothing, level 0 perks, killing zeds is your priority, getting powerful guns are a chore, people (in pub games) don't give you money when you need that last $20 for an aa12 or m32 grenade launcher, you spam and pray hoping that those big monsters will die. How come my nade didn't work when the siren screams?

You went on to play in normal, zeds are harder, that big glowy guy along with that chainsaw dude eat you alive, the patriach kills you like you are nothing. At this point, majority of first-timers went back to beginner, stayed in normal or hard difficulty and very rarely went up to the last two difficulties. Now, this is the point where most players do not continue playing. I have to say that because:

- It takes a lot of commitment to be good in this game, a lot of grinding perks (getting those medic heals, headshots, stalker kills), repetitive maps, even the old status of the game does play a part (as it is 5+ years old which in gaming industry it can be considered a bit out-dated) along with KF2 coming out in full release soon.

For those that actually stayed and grind those perks, you might finally reach a level 6 which is the highest perk level for one of the perks, finding out you can kill zeds more efficiently, less money to buy guns and ammo at trader, and killing that big glowy guy and chainsaw guy (which now you might know as fleshpounds and scrakes respectively). Nonetheless, the last two difficulties on Killing Floor can and mostly be considered as a 'filter' to see if one does actually have the will and skill it takes to survive. I myself, was a part of these players, spamming aa12 shotguns at scrakes and fleshpounds hoping they will die. But a player and a small number of other players mentioned the ineffectiveness of such methods. At this point as well, some will listen, some won't. Those who don't, will just stay in normal and hard difficulty forever, but will be hard-pressed to survive in higher difficulty.

Then, one day, after you actually meet a player who you considered as very good (or an expert or can even be considered legends) and listens, a whole new world opens up filled with even more stuff and knowledge. This factor along with a solid teamwork (which are paramount) for the last two difficulties:

- Suicidal (Even more difficult, as zed's HP and their damage goes up along with other limitations such as you can't flinch lock sc with katana, pray and spray method are detrimental. Most level 6 'hard-dwellers' would wipe a lot here. The level of teamwork is a step or two up compared to hard and specific perk roles are a must)

And once you spend hours learning from the 'expert/pro/legendary' players on multiple ways to kill sc or fp with different perks, you feel ready to take on the highest difficulty:

- Hell on Earth (The highest difficulty, perks with specific roles along with solid communication and teamwork are paramount. Patriach fight is very challenging and damages that the zeds give out along with HP are more painful. One mistake on a critical point could mean an instant wipe even when you have those expert/pro/legendary players)

At this point, you learn even more ways and tactics to survive Hell on Earth and beat the patriach. Then you realised... when you went down to normal and hard, it becomes almost too easy and people start to notice you killing fp in seconds before it even reaches the team. Before you know it, you are that 'expert' player.

It needs to be noted that the learning curve goes up exponentially from Hard to Suicidal because the multitude of skills, abilities, and knowledge learned to survive there. If you managed to read and keep on going till this point, congratulations because you are part of the top 5% of Killing Floor players.

Then.. does it end there? When you finally got all the achievements (looking at you, Schneidzekk kill while falling and the one for FP in the back with dwarf axe) ? No, actually. Because there are lots of methods to kill the big zeds (sc, fp and patriach). When you rejoice at the fact that you are finally able to properly lock the patriach with the katana/machete/knife/welder/syringe and dance around it as it tried to chain guns you, you find out there is actually a tournament... with teams all over the world trying to beat each other with the fastest time!

You took the initiative and form a team with your other expert/pro/legendary friends from different countries, you practice, find faster camp spots, certain tactics as you improved your individual and teamwork skills even more. You also find that your teammate's skills as a whole have developed significantly as well, so much that it would not be possible in a normal setting. Strategies are formed, discussions, insults, banters are made. And then tournament comes, as you play in the opening rounds which are recorded for anyone around the world to watch, you wonder to the first time you decided to actually start playing this game, the moment you actually listens to advices and how it lead you from a spam-and-pray player to a solid Hell on Earth player to actually play in a very solid team against the best teams in the world.

The training, discussions, friendships made, skills learned, I think in the end, it was worth it.
If you actually played the game till this point, then congrats... as you are probably a very solid Hell on Earth player.

For the others that might not have the same 'eagerness', it is a fun game to play with friends, and hey, burning zeds to death is fun too :P

I r8 8/8 m8.

reviewText:
I wish I had more time to play this masterpiece from Tripwire Interactive. I spent roughly 25 hours with it which is nothing as you need at least 50 to 60 hours of gametime to be able to experience the true challenge this game has to offer.

You play with your friends and the 4 of you keep eliminating hordes of zombies. After each wave you can spend your hard-earned cash by purchasing better equipment and, of course, ammunition to the available weapons. You can only visit these vendors for a short period of time. This is what you do and, basically, you keep repeating this process till the 11th wave which is the boss battle.

Now, the game has perks (skills) which refer to each weapon category. There aren't that many levels but levelling-up takes quite the time so you should keep killing these infected. Once you have levelled up decently you and your pals can go to a higher difficulty.

It is similar to Left 4 Dead in certain ways, however, Killing Floor is not as fast paced. Also, I like how the vendor is placed always somewhere else (on higher difficulties you have less time to do the shopping). In addition to this, the game encourages you to work together. The best example for that is the fact that healing others than yourself works better.

Although Killing Floor is outdated in term of graphics, its gameplay can easily compensate you for that. The sequel should be on your wishlist already if you are a KF fan!

You wouldn't expect an ex-mod to become a huge success for the shelves,but this game just managed to achieve it. For those of you who do not know.

Killing Floor is a standalone mod that was originally for Unreal Tournament 2003, created by Tripwire, the creators of the highly-acclaimed Red Orchestra games and the unfortunately terrible Defense Alliance 2. KF has you assume the role of one of several mercenary/soldier/cop/Disc Jockey fellows who are tasked with reclaiming the United Kingdom from an outbreak of Zeds"--a zombie-like biological disaster-turned-weaponized mutant series of horribly deformed creatures who's only desire is to see you splattered across the walls like some sort of new-age graffiti Picasso painting from Hell

Killing Floor is a quality game for anyone with a mouse and keyboard and there are still loads of players who still frequent the game"

reviewText:
Killing Floor is in my honest opinion, one of the best survival-horror co-op games.

As a child I spent hours playing on Unreal Tournament 2004 servers which had a modified invasion mode, allowing you to buy different weapons and skills while spawing (somewhat ridiculous) aliens, monsters and robots.

It's almost as if Killing Floor reached into my fond memories, took the concept which got me playing for hours and hours, and refined it with a slightly more dark and horrific style.

The basic concept is very simple; you shoot mutants, you get dosh, you buy bigger guns and shoot more and bigger mutants, then the biggest mutant comes for you and if you kill him you win.
What makes this game so great is that this concept is executed very well, the mutants (Called Zeds in the game) actually look as if horrible experiments were done upon them before they turned into what they are, every zed has something that makes it so much more than your standard zombie-horde (There are spider-like zeds that come out of the roof and jump at you, a zed that shoots balls of fire at you and even a zed that has projectile-destroying screams).

The zeds have a lot of tricks to take you out, but luckily for you, you have 7 perks you can choose from, each perk grants you certain abilities and a discount on weapons for that perk, as a firebug for example, you get a discount on flamethrowers and other fire-based weapons, and you get a resistance against fire-damage.
Doing certain things related to that perk will cause you to level it up, increasing the effectiveness of it, while this is very rewarding, it does take a VERY long time to level a perk up all the way to the maximum of level 6 legitimately. (I'll leave it to you to decide if that's a bad thing or not)

So, the zeds are scary and strong, perks are useful, but what about the guns?
Tripwire is known for realistic and great sounding and animated guns, so each shotgun feels powerful as you blast something to bits, each rifle has a high-recoil but also a high potentional damage output, but since this is a game with zombies, we have some some fictional guns as well, such as a fireball-cannon, a laser which can also slow down zeds, SMGs that can also shoot medic-darts at allies and much more. (There are 3 dlc weapon packs which unlock 4 weapons each, it's not pay-to-win DLC as the weapons are side-grades, not upgrades.)

Oh! almost forgot to mention that there are a lot of melee-weapons too!

The game was released in 2009, but Tripwire is still supporting it with seasonal events (Summer, Halloween and Xmas) which give the zeds themed-reskins, new maps (or Objective mode missions), new achievements and sometimes new weapons, most of it for free, but with Killing Floor 2 on it's way, I cannot guarantee that this will happen again in the coming years.

So, if you're looking for a fun and challenging survival-horror co-op game that offers you plenty of content and hours of fun, look no further, there is a wave of mutants waiting to be eradicted.. or eradicate you.

reviewText:
Кровавый (нестоль кровавый как я ожидал) co-op шутер от первого лица в жанре survival horror. Данную игру воплотили на свет чудотворцы из компании Tripwire Interactive и выпустили 14 мая 2009 года. Адриналиновый экшен, в котором шестёрке выживших предстоит отбиваться от кровожадных и голодных мутантов. Более 16 видов оружия, расчлененка и ураганный игровой процесс прилагаются.

Причиной тотального апокалипсиса стала корпорация Horzine Biotech, которая получила от государства заказ на создание идеальных солдат, и профессор  Кевин Кламели, сделавший прорыв в области регенерации (востоновлени), научился клонировать людей и управлять их разумом. Вскоре учёный создаёт огромную и безграничную армию зомби и с ней решает завоевать Великобританию.

В игре есте два режима гемплея:

1. Выживание: массовое уничтожение мутантов-зомби, несколько волн с сотней монстров, которые нужно пережить вам и вашим напарникам, а также мощнейший финальный босс Патриарх (это и есть учёный Кевин Кламели) для каждой карты. Впаги лезут изовсех щелей и нужно быть внимательным, держаться вместе и по ходу игры выробатывать тактику боя против монстров.

2. Прохождение: в игре к сожалению выбор карт данного режима пока что не велик - всего 3. Суть будет в том что вам с вашими пропагандистами нужно пройти карту, выполняя ряд заданий для дальнейшего продвижения группы вперёд и в итоге одалеть Патриарха.

В игре есть ещё 9 противников:

Зомби — самый часто встречаемый враг, может «хватать» игрока, не давая возможности ходить.

Толстяк — толстый мутант. Может как изрыгать желчь на игроков с небольшого расстояния, так и бить ножом мясника, подойдя в упор. (другие твари получают тоже урон от её желочи, наступая на неё).

Ползун — интересный эксперемент со скрещиванием гибридов человека и паука. Быстрый, малозаметный, и довольно опасный в больших количествах. (меня всегда бесят).

Берсеркер — обладает вживлённым мечом вместо правой руки, передвигается с большой скоростью, но большую часть времени существования он безопасен на расстоянии.

Сталкер —  невидимый мутант, но во время атаки становится видимой. (и в принципе её увидеть, когда она невидимая, не составляет друда).

Ободранный — противник со встроенной в руку ракетницой, довольно опасен в группах. Атакует огненной смесью на дальнее расстояние, и, подойдя вплотную, атакует врукопашную.

Сирена — медленная женщина-мутант, клонированная жена Патриарха, криком снижает здоровье и уничтожает гранаты/взрывчатку/ракеты. (броник не ломает)

Мясник — сильный мутант, чрезвычайно опасный в ярости, атакует вживлённой в руку бензопилой. (совет: в ближнем бою (тока не ножём) бейте его на небольшём растоянии и не бойтесь его бить; ваши удары немного его контузят" и в скоре вы его даже одни вальнёте).

Отбивальщик — очень сильный мутант
date: чрезвычайно опасный в ярости в которую он приходит от атак игроков
recommended: набрасываясь на них и перемалывая своими похожими на камнедробилки руками (убивайте его сразу же всей группой

reviewText:
Overall Rating: 9.9/10

Review of the main aspects of the game:

Controls 10/10
Graphics- 9/10 (considering this game started as a mod on a game ~10 years ago)
Teamplay- 10/10
The weapons 9/10 (could have more variety, but well balanced)
Level system 10/10
Balance of the Zeds (enemies)- 9.5/10 (still die inside when 5 sirens spawn behind 2 fleshpounds, and 3 scrakes)
Mods- 10/10 (Plenty of mods for reskins, more guns, more maps, even making money a weapon.)

Background information about the game for those who want to buy it:
You, and up to 5 others if you want, are sent into a living hell fighting off zeds, human experiments that have been cloned by the thousands by Horzine as 'soldiers', in the good ol' queen's country of England.  The zeds include clots, bloats, gorefasts, stalkers, sirens, crawlers, husks, Scrakes (SC), and Fleshpounds (FP). You have to stay alive for 10 waves of these horrible creatures that slowly gets progressively worse with/ as a bunch of psychopaths. Until the end of each round where you trade with a... horny? perverted? trader who will take dosh you earn from killing zeds (bounty) to give you more guns. HOWEVER! You can only carry 15kg of equipment (it increases if you're a support). There are 7 balanced classes in the game as follows: Field Medic, Support Specialist, Sharpshooter, Commando, Berserker, Firebug, and Demolitions. Finally, surviving all 10 waves you then have to fight the patriarch an evil clone of Horzine's CEO along with some lower class zeds. Killing Floor features 5 difficulties (Beginner, Normal, Hard, Suicidal, [HoE] Hell on Earth). These difficulties are built for higher leveled perks in correlation.

My personal thoughts about KF:
So I've just clocked in over 300 hours and have started to get comfortable on suicidal difficulty. So i figured it was time to rewrite my cheesy review and do a serious review for, what is now one of my favorite PC titles, Killing Floor. I got this game around a year ago after i got a steam account for ~$5 and immediately fell in love with the charm this game has.  Between the cheap one liners, slow motion decapitation, and heavy metal rifts.  Also the leveling is very addicting at first, even when you're grinding for stalkers as a commando.  However, i was just scratching the surface of this game.  Although it has a great controls for a zombie co-op game, addicting leveling, and loads of teamwork on harder difficulties. The one thing not a lot of reviews talk about is the learning curve to this game, and how well situated it feels as you level up your perks you slowly learn more and more tricks and tactics in the game that help you survive until you finally get up to Suicidal/ HoE servers with 6 man teams.  Killing Floor is so well-built compared to most games that start out as mods and has such depth to it that allows you to have fun even after you've played West London 100+ times and you're still not done with it. Not to mention how no matter how many times you successfully 1v1 a fleshpound as a bezerker, uppercut a scrake as a support, etc. you still feel like a bonafide badass.  All in all, this game is worth every penny even if it isn't on sale, or was $60 dollars currently. Why? Because this game grows on you and will give you hours and hours of entertainment as you go from dying on normal due to 1 or 2 sirens to taking down the patriarch on HoE.

Summary?: This game is great, no matter if you only want to put 10 hours into it, or hundreds upon thousands of hours into it.

reviewText:
Killing floor is a horror fps game that is similar to game elements of the Left 4 Dead series.  You go through different maps with hordes of zombies charging at you from all sides where you have to watch your back or else you could be instantly dead.  It is fun to play with four to six people including you.

Gameplay: Aiming is lackluster some with the variety of weapons you get to buy after each wave ends and another begins. Once a wave ends the trading shop is open where you spend money that you just got from fighting through hordes of zombies each wave. Your money stacks up once you kill more and more enemies and you lose money when you die before a wave ends. There is a red-line that helps guide you along your way to find the shop; though your usually given only thirty seconds of time to make it there , purchase your new weapon or weapons and buy ammo.

Graphics: Graphics are on par with the first Left 4 Dead graphics. Everything is crisp and it is well optimized for various different machines.

Community: When I look at steam charts this game is usually high up there still just like the Left 4 Dead series with how many lobbies are open and how many players play at any given time. They also have the community workshop implemented in this game where others can create some cool things.

Overall: The game feels more simplistic with its shooting mechanics then does Left 4 Dead which I like. It is fun, addictive like some other shooters like Left 4 Dead series of course and Call of Duty. You can hear zombies moaning, groaning and hear loud noises of a female zombie called a siren that let's out a large squeal before she is attacked.

10/10 Time well spent and enjoyed it better than what I have played and seen from Left 4 Dead 2.

reviewText:
Genre: Co-op Horde-based FPS
Reccommendation: Not for everyone, but a must play for zombie FPS fans
Playtime: More than 20 hours if you like the genre, further if you've got friends to play with.
Rating: 8/10
Review:

This game involves being put with a team of up to 6 players (you can play solo) against waves of mutant expirements, until you reach the final wave to fight a boss. You can pick between 6(?) specializations (or classes) that improve your efficiency with specific weapons and skills.

There is no crosshair in this game, meaning you will have to center your aim by yourself or use the iron sights properly. Weapons are quite cool and feel nice, everything around shooting feels nice in this game.

The DLC this game has is a little *too* much, and mostly it's just skins that don't affect gameplay, except for the Community Weapon Packs which include new, different and mostly fun weapons (that probably could be a bit overpowered sometimes, depending on the user).

There is one downside about this game though, and that is the community. Teamwork is rare for this game, and most of the time people decide to be a Berserker (melee specialized class) carelessly or be a Medic and not make use of their healing kit. If you do manage to find friends to play this with, it all might be better then.

Overral, as much as the community can be bad, it's a great game by itself. Very interesting and fun, and more with friends.

reviewText:
Probably the funnest game that involves killing hordes of undead~

The game has a neat perk system so you can choose a particular class and work your levels up, this makes allies being much more important with each individual role. The game has a wide variety of guns to choose from as well, and each map is highly detailed and can contain secrets/mini easter eggs for you to find.

Also with the end of each wave you have to venture out to wherever the trader will be this time around, thats right, no camping until the final wave comes.. My only complaint however is how DLC is advertised and there is so much bloody DLC. DLC for gun variations? No thanks..
(You can actually replace the DLC advertisement video with mods.)

Overall though, a fun co-op game with a decent soundtrack to fight the hordes alongside. Map design is amazing too.
8/10 for it's purpose.

reviewText: This game is so much fun. Even though the objective is always the same (survival). The addition of the killing floor Objective Mode just added to the charm of the game, giving us tasks and objectives to complete as per the modes description. What i like about the game is it never gets boring, the DLC is great, and the demands on the PC are low which is useful to those with lower end PC's who struggle to keep up with modern games, i honestly think this is one of the best FPS games to date, and for those of you don't like peer to peer competitive, then this is the game for you! All the fun of FPS, without the competitive nature of the game, just pure Co-Op, team orientated survival. So many achievements to get, lots of levels to be played, and so much fun to be had! - And you can play solo too.\n\nI would recommend this game to all players whether you are competitive or not!

reviewText:
What is Killing Floor, you ask? British People vs Zombies: The game. Complete with Dosh, Heavy Metal, more stereotypical Brits than a Monty Python sketch, and over 32 of some of the beefiest, most satisfying Zed-killing weapons you'll encounter in a video game. There's even 'Loadsamoney' himself, Mr Harry Einfeld, present and accounted for to wreck the Zed menace.

This is a game where you need to play on a difficulty higher than 'beginner' to experience. The fun of this game comes from it's challenge, and while I can understand people liking their games as easy, simple fun, the real 'survival horror' elements of this game come out when you're up against tougher enemies. I personally don't find this game scary due to the undertone silliness from all the characters models and event Zeds, but I still have a lot of fun with this game.

Despite coming out back in 2009, Tripwire Interactive have been supporting this game for the last 4 years, and with each update, event and DLC pack they've added, the game's got better and better!

So go ahead and pick up a copy of this now! Hell, get the 'bundle' copy which contains 90% of the game's DLC for only slightly more (trust me, most of it may be character models, but by god are they worth it).
If you ever wanted a video game equivalent of Shaun of the Dead, you need to play this.

reviewText:
In killing floor you fight limited waves of zombies to earn money and experience, and after each wave must visit the trader to refuel for the next wave.

This game is a little difficult to start with (coming from a L4D's background), but as you and your character gain experience at it, it will become easier. there's lots of weapons to choose from and categories of proficiencies to level up in different ways.

the default maps are very well done and most of them very big and detailed (but you dont have to use the whole map, you can stay in one place if that works for you).

LOTS of fun in co-op, and glad it supports six players in co-op instead of just 4 (yey!) !!

SO GLAD it supports local LAN play!!!!!!!!!! and you can configure map order, game style, etc easily.

i dont like the in-game bullet time much and wish you could turn it off (although, it is a tiny bit helpful when you are impossibly surrounded, but that is not often enough to like it). it dirupts the flow of the game for all players.

there are a few small bugs in the game that are minorly annoying and end up being the death of me sometimes, but I wont go into those.

For the most part this game grew on me and I like it a LOT for now. As I level up, I increase the game difficulty to keep it challenging.

reviewText:
Aside from all the le money simulator maymay jokes this game is actually great.
The money is required to upgrade weapons(like all games) but like zombie defense games should be you earn money from every ZED you kill. Depending on the difficulty you are playing you also recieve a a set amount of cash at the end of each wave.
It's always important to upgrade your armor first.
They have classes that require more money to use the required weapons, and a class that requires almost no cash.
Everytime you level a class/perk you pay less for required weapons.
If you put in the effort, you will not be paying much for any weapons at max perk level.
Very good structure the game is set up by.
Highly recommend, better than CoD and Left 4 dead.

reviewText:
Killing Floor is an online horde-style cooperative first person shooter that places you and other players in a map and forces you to fight waves of enemies. Your objective is simple; survive. Between each wave, a shop will open up somewhere on the map and an arrow will guide your path to find it. The trader has several weapons you can purchase and you can restore your armor and ammunition for a price.

The game calls itself cooperative survival horror and while the objective in every game is survival, this is straight up in your face action horror. The monsters just come at you. There are still times where you can turn around to find half a dozen monsters trailing you. It keeps piling on the mutants and raises the intensity wave after wave.

The game plays smooth, the controls are what you’d expect from a first person shooter using a mouse and keyboard. There are buttons for firing, iron sights, alternate firing, jumping, crouching, throwing grenades, reloading, running and changing your weapon. While the game lets you chose controller input, there are no native controls for it. You need to set everything yourself.

While the game excels in being just a horde-style game with waves of enemies, it is just that. The maps might be different, but you will run through the same enemies depending what wave you get to. The game is devoid of objectives outside of your own survival. The maps are large, so they do offer a variety of spaces, but you can fight in the same area of a map over and over again, even if the shops opening across the map encourage you to find a different place to do battle.

For anyone that chose to play offline, Killing Floor does offer a single player experience where you select a difficulty and face your foes alone. Your inventory consists of primary weapons, secondary pistols, melee weapons, a med kit and a welding torch. The torch is to seal doors shut to make it tough for enemies to get in. It also might keep you from getting out if a room fills with enemies, but leaving one door open and guarding it is a good enough tactic. Enemies will still drop in from the ceiling or jump off rooftops. You have health and body armor, both deplete when taking damage, but your health can be restored with some self stimulus while the armor needs to be purchased in from the trader.

To reward you your play style there are perks that you can select between waves or games. These seven perks work like classes to benefit certain styles. Each perk starts you off with a different set of weapons. These benefits are things like faster welding speed, more damage, more health, discounts on combat armor and so on.

The support specialist is good with shotguns. The sharpshooter is geared for crossbows and sniper rifles.The commando uses assault rifles and grenades. The field medic will heal others. Berserkers prefer melee weapons. Demolitions make things go boom with big weapons and firebugs make fires. The game still allows you to purchase any weapon from the store and you can get experience for any perk just by killing enemies with weapons from that class.

The graphics are great and they really add a beauty to the macabre ugliness of the gore and gruesome monsters. You’ll be exploding heads with every head shot and throwing the game into slow motion for improved accuracy. The maps have a lot of lighting effects, dreary lights, blue hues in rainstorms and a whole series of cheerful lights turned haunting by a creepy atmosphere.

The maps offer a vast variety of horrific playgrounds. Dark, sleek nightmarish landscapes. The game started with five maps, but it continues to grow. Abandon shools, hell, a creepy amusement park, ice caves, moon bases, even santa’s workshop was brought out for Christmas. New enemy skins have been produced in the game’s long existence. Its a real testament to how the developer has supported Killing Floor for this long.

The maps are free, because they need you to come back in order to purchase optional downloadable content. Everything from weapon packs and character skins. While it is a way to keep the game going to produce new content and keep you engaged, a lot of people might see it as a cash grab. Since you’re all fighting cooperatively against monsters, no one will ever be better than you, but they will just look different than you.

With that being said, there are a lot of free mods that you can download from the Steam Workshop to make your game look different and offer interesting ways to change the game. So for everything that you can purchase, there are still free things made by fans. Usually content taken from other games and franchises such as Doom 3’s monsters and Xenomorphs from the Aliens cinemas.

In terms of character customization, there are several character skins to chose from. They do nothing other than change the look of your character to other players. There are no mirrors to admire yourself in game when you’re grenading monsters to death.

Killing Floor is still a fun game and its been dirt cheap in the past. It still has a booming community, but there are other games that offer horde mode and so much more.

reviewText:
Really awesome, I'd say better than CoD Zombies.

Alrighty, time to update this review:
I've been playing this game for the majority of almost 3 years now, and I still enjoy playing it. For beginners, it has a lot of replayability value (since obtaining level six perks takes quite a while) which can take from 100-200 hours. After that, due to the Steam Workshop, there are a lot of options of playing with modded content. There are also dedicated custom servers with custom skins, perks, levels, weapons and more! (I recommend International Gaming Community btw ;) ) The gameplay isn't something to write home about, but there is something about that hooks you on. It's not as team intensive as L4D2, (as in, when there's only one person left, they're basically dead) but it does get close to that point. It's harder to understand the mechanics than L4D2 (since different weapons at different levels for different perks do different thigs to different enemies on different difficulties at different.. see what I'm getting at here?) BUT, once you get the hang of it, the game is tons of fun to play! Get a friend or two, (or three, or four, or five!) and get into a server and go spend hours and hours leveling up! :D

In conclusion, want to shoot zombies with your friends while having a level up game mechanic with different kinds of enemies and perks? Go buy this game! You won't regret it ESPECIALLY since it goes on sale all the time for as low as 5 dollars!

reviewText:
Now that the sequel has been announced I figured I'd write a review for what is perhaps my most favorite game of the past few years.

Killing Floor is a brilliant FPS survival horror, and perhaps the best (At least in my opinion) wave-based game out there. The game has a balance of gritty and serious environments and witty and morbid humor. The idea that you are working your way through a horde of genetically engineered monsters to finally go toe-to-toe with the final boss gives you that sense of achievement. And going toe-to-toe with the final boss is an achievement in itself; with traits from all other specimen combined and then some, you'll need a lot of bullets.

A key aspect of Killing Floor is co-op. with seven different perks to play as that fill different roles in a team, you're gonna have a hard time doing it alone. Synergy with other players is key; you could just as easily doom another player as opposed to helping them. There is a lot more to the game than it seems at first glance. All of the specimen have different nuances and behavioral quirks that you will need to learn to survive. Fortunately the Beginner mode is very forgiving so you have plenty of opportunity to get some practice in. However, the difficulty curve is like a brick wall; it's not uncommon for even veteran players to fall to the horde on even the lower difficulties.

The game is very community-driven. There are a lot of custom content for the game which is fully supported, and even some of the DLC and updates are filled with community-created content. You can expect new maps, weapons, enemies, characters, game modes and mutators.

Despite being an old game it still looks beautiful and has an incredible soundtrack. There is plenty of content for this game and the only people I wouldn't suggest this game to are the squeamish.

reviewText:
As it is know to all ,Killing Floor is a fantastic co-op game ,however ,if you never play it or just watching video of others' playing video ,you won't under the joy of cooperation and the fighting skill which you have to use in this game .
Many remarkable reasons contribute to how hard the game is which lead to some people direct their eyes upon this wonderful game and step back ,yes it is,it very unfriendly to new players.If you play with 0-1 level ,even Easy Mode will get your goat,especially when you play with other 5 players and all of them died left you alone to fight agaist 100+ monster ,even most of them are clot while 5-6 Bloat among them,what make it worse is that the space so small that it suddenly become a very horrific experience.Due to this fact,I give a suggestion to new player:play solo at first to promote your level,because in solo Mode monsters have less health than multiplayer Mode.Beside, the best solo map ,in my opinion ,is KF-farm for the map is the most broader one, workshop has a map whose name is KF-farm-day,which change the time from night to morning and the environment become  lighter so you won't feel very horror.
Judging from the evidence offered, we might safely draw the conclusion that this is a great coop game that you shouldn't miss(patients with 3D vertigo is another matter ):
1:multiple monsters,maps and weapons.You wont get bored with such abundant elements while play with your friends time and again.Each wave you will meet different collocation of monsters,some time in 7 wave you will meet one FleshPound with  several SC,just attack the FP shoulder to shoulder for the first,later for the SCs, a sharpshooter with a crossbow is enough to deal with them,however ,once we met 5 FP,the game became harder within a while,fortunately,
we succeed in wipe out all of them finally,or we would be wiped out.If you get bored with the official maps,many fantastic maps in workshop is waiting for you.So there is no wonder that many people play this for over thousand hours.
2,high requirement to cooperation.If anyone dead  after the wave come no long will be bad for the whole team.So cure your teammates timely and shoot the monsters which attack your mates from the back.whatever happen you should stick with your teammates.Guard a point which easy to attack monsters is a good idea but CANT DEFEND TO DEATH,the team should move according to the situation,or the whole team would be wiped out.
Above all,as far as I'm consider,though KF2 is released,there would still have many newplayers for KF1,if he/she makes mistakes you should tolerant them for you were also a  noob like them,think about the others' tolerance let you love this game.It's a coop game not a competive game,you play it just for fun,so whatever happen not let you unhappy and others' player unhappy,Of course,I don't mean you can use cheat tool ,if so,VAC is waiting for serving you.
WHAT I WANT TO SAY TO EVERY COOP GAME FAN WHO DON'T OWN THIS GAME  IS:If this game on discount,don't hesitate,just BUY IT!

reviewText:
It is a greatest game machine what I have ever seen!
Before when I bought, I have seen many of YouTube videos of this game for I can decide to I need it or not. I couldn't decide, but it was 75% discounted and I thought it is enough cheap for I can't act badly.
I told you that little story because I want to know you how I felt before I have bought that game. If you feel so what I have felt, I suggest go and buy the 'Killing Floor'. Give it a chance.

About the game.
The 'Killing Floor' is almost perfect game it own category.
Good things:
-Very optimized. It is good running on low computers.
-Generate random waves (in specified limits), so all plays isn't same.
-In higher difficult levels (if you can bear) most of players are a great team member.

Bad things:
-Rarely when I have joined a server, I am moving strangely slow. Only need to do reconnect.
-Some perks experience progress is very slow. Almost annoying. But, if you have a good friend, their can help to you make it easier get next perk level with 'Poundamonium' mutator. That is legal.
-In weaker difficult levels have a few not good or bad players. They close the doors before you in, and they go so-called 'lonewolf'.

Overall I recommend buy 'Killing Floor'.

reviewText: \nKilling Floor is a fantastic family game, which combines aspects of team building, puzzle solving, and perception. It will surely give you hours, or maybe even days of fun. When you start the game, you have the option to play by yourself or cooperative. Since this is a family game, playing solo is not recommended as it will not give you the full experience of Killing Floor. The co-op games can have up to 6 players, that means you, your brother or sister, your parents, maybe your favorite grandparents and your pet warthog. The goal is simple: Have as much fun as possible! You and your teammates will be put in classic maps like kf_abusementpark and kf_hellride. Before you can play, you will have to select a so called ''perk''. It is recommended that all players play field medic, because their special funbombs have a lovely green glow when thrown, but I'll come to that later. After everyone clicked on 'ready up' you will spawn in the chosen map. Take a moment to look around in these beautiful places, because there are many things to be seen. I myself have found a sleeping horse, a dancing robot, a man with a television head, and a mini caravan. Soon you will realize that you are in fact, holding a gun. This is a glitch that should be fixed by the developers, because people might get a wrong idea from what this game is about. It is recommended that you press 5" to switch to your love dispenser. Soon you will hear the joyful cheers of the npcs in this game. There is the Clot
date: a little elf that will hug you *with force*
hoursPlayed: the beautifully constructed snowman called ''Husk''
voteText: the Siren (who will sing for you)
helpfulPercent: Rudolph the crawling reindeer
votesHelpful: the Scrake (I think he's made out of ice cream :3)
votesTotal: the Bloat (Santa Claus)
votesFunny: the Patriarch (Bigger Santa) When these npcs hug your or give you colorful flying thingies

pi/5 would play again.

reviewText: Incredibly fun and challenging co-op game. It takes a lot of teamwork to thrive here and feels really rewarding when you survive a wave because your friends had your back. It might be showing its age, both graphically and interface-wise, but it still holds up pretty well because it's well designed and have been continually supported with new content by the devs and community. It can even be legitimately scary at times. I recommend taking your pick of DLC and mods at the workshop, there's some great stuff. I'll tell you: I'm much more excited for Killing Floor 2 and the potential Left 4 Dead 3.

reviewText:
Do i recommend Killing Floor? Hell yeah!
Starting out in KF was daunting for me, since i rarely play FPS games and my only previous experience was in Counter strike.
To top it off, i found that i didn't have on-screen crosshairs!

Needless to say, the first couple hours of playing this game usually resulted in me dying rather quickly to simple enemies like clots and gorefasts. Damn those buggers are fast..

As i continued playing the game, i learned about ammo conservation, and how to make shots count.
On lower difficulties you don't really need to worry about ammo too much - unless you're demolitions and shoot off a grenade at anything that moves.
On harder difficulties though, you really need to make your shots count, since there are more enemies, they take more shots to kill and you get less reward money for killing stuff.

I have bought this game as a gift for several friends and had a absolute blast playing it.

Grab it on sale or something, its really cheap and there's really no excuse why you can't afford it.

One of the best purchases i made on steam.

reviewText:
If you like wave-based FPS games where you can purchase better weaponry between rounds, Killing Floor most likely has your name on it. Besides having a solid arsenal, there are some fearsome and gruesome enemies to be fought.

Killing Floor takes place in England. Some scientists were toying with human tissue and ended up by mistake making zombie specimens. There are two types of modes in Killing floor : Killing Floor and Objective. Killing Floor mode is a horde defense type game. After every successful round, the player is allowed to upgrade buy more ammo for their arsenal. Every kill will equal more money for disposable income. Every new level becomes more difficult until the final boss appears. In objective mode, there are specific challenges that players need to pass against certain zombies. To win a round, at least one player needs to remain alive to win.

There are a lot of categories of weapons (or perks) to choose from as well as specific weapons. The categories are melee, pistols, support, commando, sharpshooter, firebug, demolition, field medic, berserker, perk neutral, and non-damaging. Melee weapons range from knives (almost spelt knifs), machetes, fire axes, katanas, chainsaws, claymores, sytches and a dwarves axe. Pistols range from regular 9mm to dual handcannons. Support comes in the form of shotguns, impalers, a zed" thrower and a AA12. Commando weapons include bullpup

reviewText:
I never thought I'd get so hooked to a game this suddenly and this quickly. With the different perks, different 'classes' of ZEDs and countless amounts of (custom) maps (in either mindlessly-slay-'em-all or Objective modes) - Killing Floor never really gets boring, and sometimes even though you think, oh I played so much this week, I might not want to anymore ... hahaha, well, YOU'RE WRONG.
Leveling up is quite easy in the beginning and later on takes a lot of determination (it takes quite some time to collect all the required kills/headshot/damage points etc) - but it still is fun and gives you even more purpose than just freeing a district, abandoned warehouse, or farming area one ZED at a time. The added advantages you gain with each level up are also great (and another incentive)!

The whole thing of earning money to buy your weapons is really cool. It's especially nice to see  when people really play as a team and help each other out when cash is short, or when they pick up an expensive weapon, after you tragically died defending your squad's core existence, to faithfully hand it back into your respawned hands.
Of course, playing experience always depends on your co-players, and maybe the difficulty too (Normal is actually quite challenging already), and depending on the moon phase and the godesses' benevolent minds it can be quite a frustrating experience or the most fun you've had in a long, long time - so long ago, it's such a distant memory it doesn't quite come washing to the surface but just tickles your metaphorical gamer-nose with a satisfying, nostalgic odour.

Personally I've made some great gaming friends just by excessively indulging in playing Killing Floor. With some I talk and laugh a lot, and I adore them, and others, well ... we might not talk much, but when we're facing the ZEDs side by side, wave after wave, you can just feel the bonding experience hanging thick in the air between us. We do not need to talk. We just wordlessly decapitate together. It's great!

I am very much in favour of this game and I am already anxiously looking forward to the successor - hoping that they are going to surprise me delightfully with more female playable characters. Because in Killing Floor there is the Traders, a people of monovular sisters ... clones, even? Who are in ownership of all the weapons available in these godforsaken places. No matter where you go, the ZEDs are there, the Traders are there (coincidence? I think not).
In terms of female playable characters, they are two that I am aware of.
Two.
Two?
Really?
TWO?
(And you have to buy them. You do not even get to play a default female soldier or ANYone like that).
Biggest booing!

reviewText: Killing Floor is a wave based, co-op, zombie survival game. Its addictive perk leveling system will keep me playing for days and days. This game is often compared to the Left For Dead series and while it is similar, the gameplay is very different. L4D is going from point A to B while KF is to try to survive each wave until you meet the boss. You have 7 perks/classes to choose from. Each perk has a role to play during the game and it's here that teamwork is needed to survive as the higher you go in difficulty the harder the game becomes for the entire team. You have a number of weapons to choose from depending on your chosen perk too. The game is quite easy to learn, survive each wave of specimens and go to the trader to buy weapons, armour, etc.  You'll then face the end of game boss, the Patriarch and he will take some skill to take down. He is heavily armed, and also very fast. Furthermore he can cloack making him even more of a threat as you'l often find him appearing in the middle of the team without any warning. The maps are very big and well designed too. A great team based game and i highly recommend it!

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Killing Floor
Original Release: 2009
Genre Tags: FPS; Coop; Round-Based; Progressive
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): N/A
Multiplayer Aspect: Primary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Multiplayer gamers
REVIEWKilling Floor is one of the most fun cooperative FPS games in existence. Team up with up to 5 other players to fight off waves of zombies mutants. Not necessarily groundbreaking, but somehow the concept has been reimagined in a unique and exciting way.  If you like cooperative FPS games, this should be a definite pick-up for you.

There are various types of mutants. Some are essentially “trash mobs,” but play a role in getting in the way. Then there are mid-tier and high-tier specials" that all have unique attacks. These spawn less frequently
date: but can wind up overwhelming you if you don’t take them down quickly. And if you make it through all the waves in a match
recommended: there is a boss fight. If you play on the highest difficulty and with a full team
hoursPlayed: then these boss fights are easily the most fun and adrenaline-pumping boss fights in any cooperative shooter game like this.\n\nThere are 7 classes to play as.  You can play as all classes on your account
voteText: but only one at a time; and you will permanently level-up each class by playing.  Having higher levels is a must if you want to take on the higher difficulties.  On those high difficulties the true brilliance of the gameplay really shines. You’ll have to play smart and as a team if you want a chance to beat the maps on Hell on Earth. It can be incredibly challenging
helpfulPercent: and you may go a while without winning a single match. But when you finally do
votesHelpful: it can be incredibly satisfying.\n\nHaving said that
votesTotal: it should be noted that the game also scales with the size of your team
votesFunny: and you can play solo which lowers the amount of enemies per wave and lowers their stats. Because of this
commentsCount: playing solo is actually easier for some
column16: although if you make a single mistake its game over because there is no one to pick up the slack. I personally feel the game is way more fun with full teams (and thus full enemy spawns with max stats).\n\nAlso
column17: there is a lot of DLC
column18: but don't let that turn you off.  I have not bought a single DLC for this game
column19: and have over 300 hours of fun and have nearly every achievement (except for two that I’m not worthy of).  That said
column20: a couple of the DLCs are worth getting as they grant you access to some great weapons that are very effective and fun to use. And anyone who owns any DLC can drop the unlocked weapons in game for someone else to pick up for that match.\n\nSo if you like games like Left 4 Dead or Payday
column21: this is very much in the same vein. However
column22: it also has a great unique identity. It is a sure bet for anyone who likes cooperative shooters and challenging gameplay.\n\nFollow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!"

reviewText:
Initially a very two dimensional game that while fun, lacked proper staying power, Killing Floor has grown as it's gone on.

The seasonal events and the relatively recent addition of a campaign have helped keep the game from stagnating and kept people obsessed with achievements coming back.

Not really a fan of their more recent DLC, adding weapons that tip the balance to favour players who buy DLC is not something I can agree with.

The game is only truly fun when you're playing with people who know their stuff, and who communicate and coordinate with one another.  Friends with microphones and reasonable Internet connections are what you need to make this game really work out well.

With the afore mentioned companions, it can be a fun game to throw yourself into from time to time, though a less tactical one than Left4Dead.

reviewText:
Did you know? Killing Floor was originally a mod for Unreal Tournament 2004. Did you also know it was made by the same team who made Red Orchestra, another UT2004 Mod?

Tripwire Interactive's track record is pretty good when it comes to mods to games and Killing Floor is extremely good.

You are part of a small 6 man team of varying perks to try and overcome the Zed Horde, from the simple Clot, the loud and proud Siren, the scary Fleshpound and the big bad Patriarch.  Fighting through waves, you must survive by getting mad amounts of dosh and buying bigger and badder weapons from the Trader.

Gameplay is pretty good when solo or with a group of friends, it can get frantic at times, but it's still a fun ride along the way. And if you get tired of the base game, Killing Floor can be customized like it's parent, UT2004. Though with the Workshop function, it's a whole lot easier to install mods (I recommend subscribing to the Weapons Workshop Mod for having custom weapons to work).

Map are generally ranged from close quarters to rare big and large maps, and the visuals are pretty decent.

My major gripe is with the music, a lot of it's heavy metal stuff, but over time the music just becomes grating and uninteresting. There's stuff in the Workshop to change the music, but MP3 support would be nice.

And after a while Killing Floor does become wholely reptitve, even the objective mode gets tedious because there's not a lot of maps for it. But it's still a good dame throughout and I whole-heartedly reccommend it for those who like zombie games.

reviewText:
You can ♥♥♥♥ cash if your squad survives.

11/10










Though joking aside, I feel the need to write a serious review for the first time in a damn long time.

This is one of the best co-op games, if not THE best co-op game, out there. In fact, IMO nothing is better except for the map oc_wildfire from Obsidian Conflict, but nobody plays that dead mod anymore. In KF, not only did the community remain large despite the passing time, but so did the addition of new content. I regret not getting this sooner. This is the closest thing to my dream game. The only thing this game lacks that my dream game (which I searched for extensively, but it doesn't exist!) is that it isn't F2P and it doesn't have any really strong puzzle aspects to it.

When I got this, I knew I would love it. But there are small little things that I didn't expect.  Time slowing down sometimes when somebody makes a nice kill, pressing a weapon category automatically pulls out the most expensive (and presumably most powerful) weapon in that category, turning on the flashlight automatically brings out the most expensive (and presumably most powerful) weapon with a flashlight, the soundtrack, etc. I feel as if Steve Jobs worked on this game.

It's truly magnificent and I'm probably gonna play it for a damn long time.
