reviewText:
I really love this game.

Is it kind of a grind? Yea but if you really hate the grind, you can easily DL a perk leveler map and train your stats if it bothers you that much.

Is this game repetitive? Sure but that's also a key factor which makes it great. You know what is going to happen but on the harder levels, the antsy feeling of running away and shooting or barricading yourself in somewhere never goes away and that's awesome.

Really just a big sandbox game. A lot of fun without friends but if you have friends, it is way more fun. The teamwork you get on some servers to stick together and watch everyone's backs is awesome and hilarious.

I put this game down sometimes because of how repetitive it is but I always come back for more. Hopefully Killing Floor 2 will just learn from the few mistakes this game had and make a better version.


If i were to recommend a game that's wave-based, shoot-em-up with twenty-five or more guns that you use efficiently against armies of failed experiments that give you bounty cash when you kill them, so you can kill that in horrifically more brutal ways with better guns, as they slowly upgrade their army with bigger baddies until you fight an all-mighty boss that could rekt you without blinking, I'd recommend Killing Floor.

Seriously, this game is my TOP FAVORITE, just because of how enjoyable it is. Yes, it may be old, and yes, it's not graphically impressive, but it's a damn good game. It has me STILL playing, even after hitting rank six with every class and gaining every annoying ♥♥♥♥ing achievement.


Why do i keep playing? Because it's fun, and because my friends have/love it. Playing by yourself on Hell on Earth, doesn't compare to the simple mayhem of playing with 6, or 64 other players (depending on what player-based mods are installed.) And, if you don't like the original ZEDS, you can re-mold them with extremely well-done mods like the Killing Floor: Dead Space mod, or the Aliens mod, to fight more horrific creatures. Hell, they even have mods to make the game ALMOST like DOOM.

There is weapon mods, character re-skins, maps, VEHICLES, and so many other amazing things. This game gets a 10/10, no matter how people string the BS. It's a great game, and has some amazing re-play value when you're trying new things out. Multiplayer is fun, single player is fun, and PLEASE don't say that popping a ZED's head of with a M99 ISN'T satisfying.

10/10 best zombie shooter genre game of 2009-2015 (KF 2 EA in april of 2015)

It's truly magnificent and I'm probably gonna play it for a damn long time.

reviewText:
Killing Floor is a co-op game, where you can play alone, about experiments gone wrong and invading London (and the world too as seen in KF2 and as seen on some KF maps). Your goal is to survive 4,7 or 10 waves of enemies, while earning money by killing them (or by healing your teammates) so that you can buy powerful weapons during the minute of calm at the trader between the waves. After, you'll have to defeat the Patriarch, who is the sole responsible for the chaos. You can choose different difficulties: Easy (which is really to learn the game), Normal, Hard, Suicidal and Hell on Earth.

Enemies are thougher depending on the difficulty but you too can evolve and acquire advantages like spawning with a better weapon than a pistol or armor thanks to the level system. You have 6 of them and it takes time. However, you have different classes: medic (no powerful weapon but more resistance  and better health), commando (rifles and can see stalkers from apart), support (big guns and better welder), demo (everything that is explosive), berserker (melee and also can't be grabbed), sharpshooter (sniper and headshots more efficient) and firebug (flame everywhere).

Enemies are varied: from the simple Zed to the infamous Fleshpound that can kill you quickly, without forgetting the Scrake and the chainsaw, the Gorefast that cuts you in pieces, the Crawler that loves your feet, the Stalker who is hidden, the Husk that launches fireballs, the Siren that is hurting your ears (and your health)....

Anyway, the game in its actual state contains many maps (some are official, others done by modders) and mutators with Christmas-themed or Halloween-Themed or Circus-Themed enemies (because they were parts of special events). The maps are very varied: fair, tunnel of love, Santa's workshop or cave, asylum, Horzine labs, urban town, mountain, hospital, etc..

But you'll ask me: what about the DLC? Well, all the DLC are cosmetic. True, you have new weapons in them and they can be used for achievements. However, you can do them with the standard weapons, that are enough like the AA12 for example. And you can unlock avatars by playing with themed mutators for example or owning other games. And that's how you own two Mr Foster (the normal and the steampunk).

Killing Floor in solo holds interest if you want to level without having a team to check or to win map achievements in Normal/Hard. An higher difficulty is better with a team, however, keep in mind that some of the players aren't using the perks for the team but for themselves. I've seen many medics choosing this perk for the advantages it's giving in terms of resistance or health but not healing at all the team for example. It's annoying as hell and if I seems to be upset by this kind of behavior, it's because I'm a medic first in this game, because I feel more useful by healing my teammates than beginning to put pipe bombs, welding the right doors or being a specialist of the crossbow. Healing is important in that game and if a medic is there, he's more powerful for the heal than the rest of the team. Not using of that fact can result in premature death on high difficulty.

Anyway, with Killing Floor 2, I don't know if there are still a lot of players there. I still need to win Suicidal and Hell on Earth achievements, as I've all Hard and Normal and that all my perks are lvl5+. But it's still worthy to play. As long as there are servers and as long as the solo mode is there, Killing Floor is really a very strong co-op game. However, make sure that you're not discouraged when level 0. By patience, by learning and by leveling, you'll find more and more pleasure to survive these waves.

reviewText:
I got this game during the Halloween Sale after being interesting in it after watching Roosterteeth do a 'Lets Play' of it, and I must say that is a very fun game to play either by yourself or with friends as a team.

This is a wave based game pitting you and/or a team against 10 waves of ever increasingly diffcult monsters, each with thier own unique way of making surviving difficult for you. After beating the 10th wave you and your team are pitted against the 'Patriarch' who will test you and your teams skill and ability to work together to the max.

+ Fun and simply gameplay to learn.
+ Huge arsenal of weapons to destroy your enemies.
+ Very creative set of maps with the game constantly including new maps created and recommended by the community.
+ Funnest game to play with your friends.

- Can be cruel if you die during a wave as you lose your weapon and some ingame money.
- Whole team dying except one on wave 10 can make respawning and then fighting wave 11 almost impossible.

Overall this is very fun game to play, with developers who respect the community by importing custom made maps in, and also custom made weapons offcially imported, also more awaits in the Steam Workshop.

Overall Score: 7/10

reviewText:
Killing Floor is an incredible co-operative survival shooter. You can play solo, or join up with up to 5 other players to face waves of specimen trying to kill you. The specimen are enemies with big variety. Some are weak but can be tough in groups. Some are tough and can kill your whole squad single-handedly if you're poorly prepared.

After each wave the game will progressively become harder, and tougher specimen will spawn. Between each wave the trader will open up her shop and you will be able to purchase a variety of weapons. You all have a perk that gives you bonuses and makes you more effective with certain weapons and levels up as you play. For example Support specialist are good with shotguns, commandos with assault rifles, berserkers with melee weapons and so on. After all rounds are complete you will face the final boss, the patriarch, and your teamwork will be put to the test.

The game can get rather difficult. One big part about this game is the progression and the long learning curve. You won't be able to beat every map on the first try. You will learn about the enemies, the maps, the perks and the weapons as you play. And after mastering a difficulty you can move on to a higher difficulty and the rules will change. You will need new spots to defend at, new weapons to use and new tactics. This might be a drawback to some, but to somebody who likes long learning curves, it's perfect.

The graphics are very good but not the latest. The game is from 2009 but still has impressive graphics. It's well optimized and can run well on decent hardware. The maps varies in quality but some are very well made and makes for a very good atmosphere. The game has quite some gore. It is well made and can be enjoyed during the Zed time. Zed time is when the whole server goes slow motion for a few seconds. Watching a Fleshpund blow to pieces right before you just as he about to shred you to pieces in slow motion is nothing short of awesome.

The audio is also very good. The sound effects and the music are well made. The music changes from map to map and really adds to the atmosphere. It's fast-paced during the waves and makes shooting specimen a lot more fun.

Killing Floor also has season events, three times a year. Every summer, halloween and winter all skins of the specimen change  during the event. New maps, weapons and achievements are also introduced. It keeps the game constantly fresh and always fun to come back to.

Killing Floor is a really great game. It has improved a lot since it was released and still does wth constant updates. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Experimentin' stuff has gone bad. Crazy experiments are on the loose. Whole cities are abandoned (or all inhabitants are exterminated, but hey, no one had time to inform you about that!). No one knows where you are, but as a cold comfort: most people don't even care whether or not you survive, so even if they could, they wouldn't help you. You and your squad are on your own, surrounded by experiments and weird humanoid-looking-ish fusions that are basically your worst nightmare, and theyre out there to eat you. Exterminate them all or they will have you grilled medium rare for dinner.
AND AS IF THAT WASN'T BAD ENOUGH YET, once you destroyed enough experiments, the creator and 'father' of them will appear, and he wont be happy! But who could blame him? You'd be mad too if a random squad of 6 weirdos would come and kill hundreds and hundreds of your children!
This is the premise of Killing Floor, a first person shooter that brings you to a (maybe not so original, but who cares, as long as you can shoot things) scenario in which you're the last men standing against monstrous opponents. With a good variety of enemies and five difficulty levels, this game is gamer-friendly for the newbiest of newbies and challenging for the experienced exterminator, whereas every different enemy will require a different strategy to get rid of when you play on the highest difficulty level. You will level up your classes on the go to match your characters abilities with the level you'll be playing on. With the 7 different playable classes (or Perks) you can play your preferred role in a team, so you'll have your favourite way of destroying evil: Fightin' (or kitin') like a MAN? play Berzerker. Steady aim, ready to take out the big threats? play Sharpshooter. Do you like to watch the world burn? play Firebug. Like gibs flyin' around and explosions? play Demolitions. Assault rifles 'n kalashnikovs 'n stuff? play Commando. Wanna be that guy that carries a million different (and heavy) guns? play Supports specialist. Do you love ze healing, not ze hurting? play Field medic!

This all comes with a sh*tload of different maps in completely different settings (woods, buildings, cities, north pole, on a ship, on the moon, EVERYWHERE), able to keep your interest for quite a while. Also contains objective modes to keep the diversity in the game.

STILL haven't had enough? There's an incredible amount of custom content with EVEN MORE perks to level up to even greater heights, additional objective modes with a wide range of different goals to achieve.

To top this off, your squad consists of whiny, cocky british people with a strong accent, so insults, directions and calls for help will sound hilarious! Despite many negative remarks on the 'crappy' voice acting, I actually think the lack of seriousness these squad members show with their snarky voice commands adds nicely to the game's attractiveness.

Pros:
- A million different guns
- Dont like guns? It has explosives too
- AND fire
- AND melee weapons
- Playable at all skill levels
- A lot of variety in the maps
- Challenging and interesting action on higher levels (especially as berzerker in my opinion)
- Enemies with chainsaws
- A boss with a machine gun for an arm
- ^I forgot to mention his OTHER arm is a FRIGGIN' ROCKET LAUNCHER
- Has nice skin overrides with christmas, halloween and in the summer.
- Help me or I'll be pushin' up the bloody daisies!"

Cons
- By far not the best graphics (Don't get me wrong
date: they're not terrible!)\n- Camping to survive waves on high difficulty can get stale easily (but there's kiting to make up for that)\n- Not the most serious and realistic shooter (I personally don't mind
recommended: but I know many will see this as a downside)\n\n"YOU MURDERED MY CHILDREN": prepare to fight
hoursPlayed: stock up on the biggest
voteText: baddest guns and bombs and sht and take the challenge! A great gore-spattered shooter that will be guaranteed entertainment for a long time!\n\nRating: 9/10"

reviewText: A simple concept with surprising depth, survive a finite number of zombies in each wave, and try to make enough cash to buy better weapons for the next one, All the while hoping to end up with suitably powerful weapons for the end of game boss. The different perks(classes) provide a great variety in the way you play this game, and an RPG like upgrade path. Different environments require different strategies as well. If you just try and blast everything, you will probably fail, so learning the different abilities and weaknesses of the Zeds is important. The different game difficulties require you to master new tactics and tricks in order to be successful. The achievements make you want to keep playing and the social aspect of working with friends is very satisfying. Single player also requires different tactics to multiplayer coop. I have been playing this for a long time now, and still get surprised at how unique each game can be. One of the all time best coop games ever. The setting can be a bit macabre, so not for younger kids though.

reviewText: This is a game you shouldn't play at night. I play it often with my friends, and im either doing REALLY bad or im doing REALLY good. It tends to be the first. I love playing this game with friends because I know 70% of the time I can rely on them. The other 30% they are trying to screw me up. I had this one glorious moment where I was the lone survivor on Medium Difficulty and there were 50 or so monsters left, + a Fleshpound and 3 scrakes. I was out of ammo, it was an intense 10 minutes of me running around, self healing, and shooting the FP every now and then. I am the person on the team who doesnt wanna go against a Scrake let alone 3 and a FP, but I did it. The rest were easy, and I saved my team. The next round I died within a minute. Thats how this game can change. I love the speed of it, the graphics, the controls, and the multiplay. No way I could play this on my own. I scare so easily T_T.\nI would give this game an 8.5/10 :)  Its definetly a game to play with friends, I recommend it for people who have 5 good friends you know you can mess around with, and have a good shooting time. I just hope you aren't afraid of the darkness.

reviewText:
Killing Floor is one of those solid historic PC games that i'll always love to play. It never gets old or boring for me no matter how many times i play it. It's difficult and the igher rounds can become a real challenege if you don't prepair in the right way early on. I still have issues with the game itself at times. It's pretty frequent the issues i run into this game. The weapon dlcs are also a great buy as well, i normally don't pay for dlc on steam but KF i've bought almost all of the weapons ones. Playing by yourself is a great way to kill time, but plaing online is a real challenege and defianatly a blast to do if you have the right teammates. You have a set of about 6 different classes all of which you level up by using weapons and sometimes equipment in their field. The higher the level of the class the cheaper you can buy the guns for it and the more powerful they become, faster you can reload, and also different perks depending on the class. The enemys are pretty well balanced with a good mixture of powerful enemys and weaker ones. You can also use different enemies for your advantage and get them to kill the zeds for you(Fleshpoun and Bloater).
The workshop for this game is also really good. You can find all sorts of things in there to enhance the gameplay. Adding new guns to the game(LMG, Snipers, Assault Rifles etc) you can add maps made by the community that are well done and balnced out, and also get different game modes and also some pretty cool mods to change the whole game up and give it a different field (Aliens mod)
As much as i hate dealing with a game that has issues i still love Killing Floor becasue it's iconic to me and one of the best PC games i've played. It's a game that sticks out there from all the rest and it's one that's fun and challenging all at the same time.
(os being used is Mac)

reviewText:
One of the best shooters I've owned and played.

-You shoot, burn, blow up, and slice failed experiments (not zombies). You have unique perks for the class you choose, which is important when you play co-op or solo on higher difficulties. The atmosphere and hordes of enemies coming at you just make it frightening. Just the thought of having hordes of different enemies come at you makes you want to hole up somewhere and weld the doors!

-I like how the game has characters with emcumberance/weight so you can carry as many weapons as your weight limit allows. Support class does this best.

-Although there are DLC weapons for purchase for real money, the best weapons are already available in the shop. You really aren't missing out if you don't buy the DLC.

-You hit what you aim for. LOL (Unlike some other FPS)

-If only this game had a vs player version.

Good buy for me

reviewText:
The best co-op game I've played!

KF is basically waves of different zombies coming to get you and nomnomnom you to death.
It doesn’t sound too complicated and it’s not. Don’t mix up simplicity with fun though – I don’t see any dependency here.

Everything depends on who you play with and everybody’s play style. This is the factor that could make you rage or laugh or chill during the whole game.
I’ve experienced one and the same map and difficulty to be easy, extremely hard, annoying or raging, all depending on who I play with.

What the game is like? As I said – waves and different zombies. There are also 6 classes you can play as and all of them have different strengths and weaknesses, as well as different nemeses in the face of the different zombie types. There are no skills that you can choose from, so all who choose to play a certain class are equal (at least until the point when it comes to skills, situation assessment and general play style). Weapons are also divided in classes, but there is no restriction if you feel like buying a weapon meant for a class different than yours.

reviewText: This game is pretty good. It's one of those Gears of War horde mode/Call of Duty zombies mode type games where you stay in one area and fight off the enemies while trying to survive. Killing enemies gives you money, and here is where the game does something very smart, you can share the money. You can even share guns. Also the health system is so that you can heal teamates faster than you can heal yourself. These mechanics actually promote teamwork.\n\nIt's not an incredibly polished game like some AAA titles, but it is good where it counts and is worth your time if you enjoy co-op shooters and don't mind the graphics being a little rough around the edges. I give this game 4 flesh-pounds out of 5.

reviewText: Killing Floor is one of the greatest cooperative game to ever come out on Steam. Is it really? Definitely. Since the game was debut in 2009, Killing Floor evolved with many seasonal events, free weapons and maps, and small cosmetic downloadable content to support Tripwire Interactive's longevity to Killing Floor. One would ask: What is Killing Floor? Well, Killing Floor is a six player multiplayer cooperative survival game that takes on against various zeds"
date: ranging from the clots to the rage-meter Fleshpound that will grind your body into giblets. There are seven perks that you can select that varies from the Support Specialist with its ultimate shotgun barrage to the fast running Berserker that you will probably become the "ultimate ninja" if you play long enough (Berserker is my favorite perk to use; it's really fun). The game may become a bit repetitious
hoursPlayed: playing with your friends
voteText: or meeting (and making friends) with other players in the Killing Floor community will make you come back and enjoy killing those zeds.\n\nDid I mention zed time (or slow motion)? There is and seeing zeds being decimated is an appeal to the eyes. The last question remains: Do you have this game in your Steam library? If not

reviewText:
Ah, Killing Floor. That Game with wierd events (Hill Billy Horror) and Brilliant Cameos (Portal 2). Let's break this one down shall we? Let's start off with the thing I love the most. Gore = Detailed. However, your not gonna be puking your heart out by looking at it. It gives you your classic exploding heads. Blasting off arms and having specimens run off with the left leg in their hand. It's detailed and statisfying.
Now we should start with waves. Waves are large since these specimens come in numbers. You can expect 90+ specimens on a large map at wave 3 out of 10. Yes, there are 10 waves. At the end of these ten waves, the end game boss, The Patriarch, will appear to hunt you down. But we'll get to that later.
Now, Weapons. Weapons are by far the most important thing you will grasp in your hands. But weapons are weapons and I am pretty sure everyone knows how to use a gun. So we'll cover the welder and the syringe. First, Welder. A unique abillity in this game is to weld doors to give you time to prepare for the horde behind those doors. The Welder, while it has an infinite usage, you need to give it a break when it reaches about 60% through to welding the door. It runs on power and will need a quick recharge. Second, the syringe. This pretty little red syringe will be your angel. Infact, your teams angel. Everyone carrys one and it allows a team to stay alive for longer periods of time. I can not stress the amount of times this has saved my life, and my teams life. You use M1 to heal others with it and M3 (Middle mouse) to heal yourself. Healing yourself isn't as effective as someone healing you but it will save your life.
Lastly, Specimens. Clots,Gorefasts,Bloats,Stalkers,Sirens and so much more. I am going to cover the specimens abillitys and what they look like so then you can easily indentify them.
Clots, the weakest specimens. They do have a nasty habit of grabbing you and not letting go. You will know them when you see them. Just zombies basiclly.
Gorefasts are clots who charge at you with a big nasty machete stuck into his arm. Again, You'll know it when you see it.
Bloats, the boomers of Killing floor. He didn't enjoy his KFC and now he is going on a puking rampage. He is so fat, he is the slowest specimen in the game. He carrys a butcher cleaver. And his vomit is corrosive.
Stalkers are basicly partially visbile clots that like to utter ''Give us a kiss....'' You can see their skeletal structure in bright maps when thier invisible.
Sirens. SHOOT THE *****, SHE'S DOING MY HEAD IN. She loves to also utter give us a kill. Deny her with that gun up her throat and your in for a toddler tantrum. She loves to scream. Infact, her screams are so loud, it will destroy frags and rockets. She looks like she had a bad hair day.
Skrakes, Yes that is a chainsaw he is carrying. Nothing Subtle about him. Anger him too much and he'll run up for the kill. The Skrake that is, not you.
Husks are rocket shooting skrakes basiclly, and he isn't very good at melee combat. Looks like a zombie megaman.
FleshPounds. Besides the Patriarch, these guys are rock tough. They are the Unsunken Titanic. And they have came to rip you to shreds. and JESUS CHRIST WHATS THAT HE'S GOT ON HIS ARMS?! I'll tell you what it is. It's a spinning metal spiked gauntlet. If this guy either stays out of combat too long or takes too much damage at the same time, He'll go on a bloodthirsty rampage and attempt to destroy the scums he calls your team. Looks like he got surgery by Richard Trager. (I will love you if you get the reference)
Last but not least, The Patriarch. The end game boss. HE is the strongest thing alive in the game. Your team must prepare for him. Buy your armour and bombs. He is capable of 1 hit killing you if you stand to close. Attack from a distance. And watch out for the nasty guns he has. Rocket Launchers and Chain Guns. He will be the one to wipe you off the face of the planet. He is also Capable of running off and healing himself. Don't let him do that.


Thanks for reading my review of Killing Floor!

reviewText:
Killing Floor is by FAR my favorite game on Steam. This is because of many reasons.
A. It has a VERY dedicated, mature, and friendly fanbase.
B. Most of the time, players will actually help you in this game
C. Amount of Characters are endless and growing
D. Weapons are also endless
E. There are 7 classes, that take several months of playing to fully level up
F. The enemies are brutally tough, but trust me, this is a good thing.
G. You can play it on high graphics with just about any computer.
H. Every holiday, the enemies change appearance and more achievements are unlocked around killing the new enemies.
I. (Using Steam Workshop and downloading the song Boss Wave" to play during the final boss. Love hearing that song when fighting the boss.)

Bottom line is
date: I freaking LOVE this game and I always manage to come back to it and wreck more havoc in it. Give this game a shot

reviewText: One of the best co-op games I have played in my entire life. Not enough games emphasize team-play like this one does. There are 7 perks you can play as, and all serve a specific purpose. On the lower difficulties it's not that important, but on the higher ones you really need a balanced team to make it through. Each of these perks can be levelled up, giving you several bonuses which make the game generally easier. It's also an addicting mechanic that more survival/horde games should have. The soundtrack kicks so much ♥♥♥ too. I also really like the developers because they do something special every holiday, like releasing a new map and adding a new unlockable character. But there are also thousands of custom maps and other mods made by the community to use. The game goes on sale with a huge discount so often, and you get so much value and content for your money.\n\nIf I have one complaint about this game the way it is now, then it's that it doesn't look as dark and scary as the original mod did. The maps looked a lot darker and really seemed like how places would look during a scenario like this. It had a better atmosphere, in my opinion. The new maps just look too clean, but they are designed better in the sense of enemy spawn points and being able to survive on them.

reviewText:
This game is one of the best FPS Co-Op ever made. In fact, it may be the best Co-op ever made. It's certainly the best one I've ever played.

If you've ever read any of my other reviews, you know that something special is coming if I start like that...

So. Yes, it's an older game (2011 I believe). I'm glad we've got that out of the way. The graphics do feel a tiny bit dated, but they are clean, and you soon forget about it.

Admittedly, I haven't played it for a while, so I'm a little bit rusty, as some of the small things I love about the game probably won't be posted here, but I just realised I haven't written a review for it, and it really needs one. So in one sentence, what makes this a great game is

Truly co-operative gameplay"

That's it
recommended: in just 3 words.\n\nThere's lots of other little mechanics that make it interesting
hoursPlayed: and sometimes slightly difficult to get into (in other words there's a little bit of a learning curve)
helpfulPercent: it's a Player Vs Environment 1st person shooter for 1 to 6 players to work in a team. In this case
votesHelpful: the environment happens to be waves of Zeds (clones that strangely seem to resemble zombies). Those waves begin with weaker creature types
votesTotal: and build up in a variety
votesFunny: difficulty
commentsCount: and number of enemies in each wave. Between waves you make your way to a shop to upgrade your weapons. Anyone who died during the wave
column16: respawn's at this point
column17: as long as one person from the team is still alive. The final wave has a "big Boss" who can heal himself a couple of times and throws small waves at you while he is healing. If you do enough damage to him
column18: you can kill him before he can run off to heal. That's the basics. There's a huge variety of the maps
column19: with more being released often
column20: in the developers are still working on making this a better game even though they're about to release the new version. That says a lot for the developer.\n\nA little bit about the mechanics of the game;So
column21: 1st person shooter. We've got that much sorted. You choose a "Perk"
column22: (otherwise known as a Class) including Medic
column27: assault. Each class has its strengths and weaknesses
column28: each class can choose any type of weapon
column29: but you get additional bonuses for using weapons that your class is designed for
column30: for example snipers get extra head shot damage while using rifles
column31: berserker's get a 30% speed boost while using a melee weapon (axes/swords etc).\n\nMore Mechanics;You start with a pistol (and a completely useless knife)
column32: and that the end of each wave you go to a trading floor where you can buy bigger and better weapons. You do have a weight restriction so you can only purchase so many weapons
column33: and the more weight you have
column34: the more your movement speed is slowed down (this is only very minor).\n\nThe more you play a perk
column35: the better your perks get… Basically an unlock system
column36: there are 6 levels to unlock for each perk
column37: and the higher the level of your perk the cheaper your weapons get to purchase in the game
column38: and the better bonuses you get on your weapons. At level 6 perk
column39: you spawn with another weapon besides just a pistol.\n\nThe most important aspects of this game
column40: are voice communication and teamwork. And that
column42: is why I love this game so much. Everyone that plays this game
column43: wants to be part of the team. There are very few 12 year olds screaming "n00b scrub”(a.k.a. none)
column44:
and very few "Rambo hero's".



Teamwork; People call when they need to swap positions
column46: or when a Z that needs a different class to deal with it turns up.\nIf you die
column47: you lose everything but;\nYour friends can pick the stuff up off your dead body and give it back to you.\nYour friends can drop money for you
column48: see you can buy more weapons.\nThere are different classes
column49: each with definite strengths and weaknesses
column50: and you need a combination of them in order to be successful. For example
column51: snipers are good at picking off big strong guys at a distance
column52: and supports (with the many shotguns) are much better suited to wave clearing the smaller guys. A sniper plus support combo will do a lot better than 2 snipers.\nAnyone can heal anyone
column55:
healing a teammate does 100%.
Headset microphone are a must for this game.

Map design;There is a huge amount of variety in the maps
column56: including some community-based built ones. One of the most interesting aspects of the map design
column57: is that maps tend to be largely "circular"
column58: it's very difficult to find a corner that you can hide in a shoot everything from one direction
column59: there's almost always more than one way for them to get in
column60: and one of those ways is directly behind you at any time -thus
column61: teamwork. This particular mechanic of the game actually does something to make it something special.\n\nThe Trader;Also known as the shop. This is another interesting mechanic
column62: which while making the game easier (read: the guns) also makes it harder. How? Because there are several spawn points for the Trader on the map
column63: often on opposite sides of the map. This makes it more difficult
column64: because if you do happen to have a good little spot
column65: you have to run to the other side of the map so you can buy more ammunition
column67: and guns. Once you are familiar with how the Trader works
column68: it's actually a very easy system to choosing the weapons and classes that you want. It's very well implemented. And the mechanic of the Trader moving
column69: really makes it feel like you're on the run from the Zeds. There is a time limit on getting to the shop and purchasing items
column70: this time limit is triggered on the last Zeds’ death. Keep the last one alive until everyone gets to the shop.\n\nDifficulty levels;The more people in the team
column71: the more Zeds you have to face together. For example
column73: 2 people would face 25 Zeds. Difficulty levels are set by the server
column74: so you can tell what difficulty level is before you log in. Difficulty is ramped up in a few ways
column77: there are more of them in a wave
column78: and they can do more damage. Also
column79: you have less time to get to the shop and buy. The hardest difficulties are called "suicide" and "hell on earth" for a reason.\n\nStoryline;Some random scientist was experimenting on humans and made clones
column80: which got out of control went on a rampage and killed lots of people. You and your team get paid to go in and clear out these infestations. The big boss happens to be That Scientist. That's the whole storyline
column81:
right there. Now go shoot some Zeds.


New players;I highly and thoroughly recommend that new players spend a significant amount of time in "solo" mode
column82: which is the single player mode of the game. I'd suggest getting each class to level II before you jump online
column83: but at the very least you need to get each class to level I.\n\nKey bindings;These are the changes that I made
column84: I feel that they make the game more intuitive. I disable weapons selection of via middle mouse button
column85: and I use the numbers 1 through 4 keys for that purpose.\nI use mouse scroll to throw money. It is much easier to roll the mouse
column86: than trying to spam a button.\nI set voice communication to my thumb (back button) on the mouse.\nI did a re-bind of my right mouse button
column87: and changed it from toggle weapons to zoom
column88: to Quick Iron Sights.\nWow. I ran out of room. I had m..."

reviewText:
I whole heartedly recommend the base game, as you can see I have spent more than 1k hours playing so there must be something to it. :D  It has changed a lot since I started playing and I'm continually amazed they have kept this outdated tech running and running pretty well for the most part. That said it does have issues from time to time, balancing that can be well just out there, and I really don't care for the weapon packs they sell but I just don't buy them, sorted :D I really haven't played in quite some time seriously I'll jump on and play during the special events but even those don't really draw me in like they used to but with 1k+ hours in a game how can I not recommend it, plus it's on sale more than it's not so pick it up next sale and have some fun with it.



The Action

The simple version is you pick a class, the class has perks that give you bonuses to weps or game mechanics, you fight in between 4 and 10 waves of specimen (manufactured zombies), then have a final boss battle,   you kill the specimen  or engage in activities to earn points toward leveling up your perk and earning money,  your perks are persistent so each session you play you continually build on them but you must earn money fighting through the waves to buy the gear you need to beat the final boss.  Each wave is progressively more difficult but more rewarding so hopefully you are able to fully kit out your toon by the time the last wave is over, in between the waves you get to go shopping at the trader (you will love her taunts) and buy new gear, sell gear you find, or gear you no longer need.   Sounds pretty simple?, it is but it is so very addictive :D



The Good

reviewText:
The point of the game is killing experimental monsters which takes place over many floors, so you could say the name says it all. But even with its lack of plot, I find Killing Floor to be a fun and challenging game.

In Killing Floor you play in first person, possibly with friends, fighting nine different kinds of specimens that roam the map looking for people to kill, becoming more numerous and releasing different specimens as the waves go by until waves 10 (if you are playing a full game) you encounter the boss, the Patriarch, who has the combined abilities of all the other specimens. Most of the regular specimen are easy to kill, with either a head shot or a shot close up with a shot gun blast to one shot them, but if someone yells Flesh Pound (FP), get some ground and prepare for a grinder.

There are seven different classes (called Perks), Field medic, Support specialist, Sharpshooter, Commando, Berserker, Firebug and Demolition which all specialize in different weapons and abilities. Also, The game has a leveling system, which varies between the different perks, mostly based off the weapons use. Such as the Sharpshooter building levels on head shots with pistols, rifles and crossbows. Having a higher level brings down the cost of weapons and increase their efficiency, which makes you start at the lower difficulties to work your way through the level to beat the harder difficulties.

Over all I love playing Killing Floor with friends and will keep playing for years to come.

reviewText: One of my favorite FPS games of all time. The community is great, the shooting mechanics feel fantastic, there's a lot of variety in the maps (especially when you include the community-made ones) and it's always a deent challenge even after playing for hundreds of hours, making for a lot of replayability. It's got the perfect mix of gore and dark humor, and the animations when you score a headshot or a particularly large explosion are very satisfying. My only criticism is the in-game voice chat, as it's pretty bad quality, but then again most in-game chat is so use Mumble or Teamspeak with friends and you'll be fine. One of the best zombie shooters out there by far.

reviewText:
I whole heartedly recommend the base game, as you can see I have spent more than 1k hours playing so there must be something to it. :D  It has changed a lot since I started playing and I'm continually amazed they have kept this outdated tech running and running pretty well for the most part. That said it does have issues from time to time, balancing that can be well just out there, and I really don't care for the weapon packs they sell but I just don't buy them, sorted :D I really haven't played in quite some time seriously I'll jump on and play during the special events but even those don't really draw me in like they used to but with 1k+ hours in a game how can I not recommend it, plus it's on sale more than it's not so pick it up next sale and have some fun with it.



The Action

The simple version is you pick a class, the class has perks that give you bonuses to weps or game mechanics, you fight in between 4 and 10 waves of specimen (manufactured zombies), then have a final boss battle,   you kill the specimen  or engage in activities to earn points toward leveling up your perk and earning money,  your perks are persistent so each session you play you continually build on them but you must earn money fighting through the waves to buy the gear you need to beat the final boss.  Each wave is progressively more difficult but more rewarding so hopefully you are able to fully kit out your toon by the time the last wave is over, in between the waves you get to go shopping at the trader (you will love her taunts) and buy new gear, sell gear you find, or gear you no longer need.   Sounds pretty simple?, it is but it is so very addictive :D



The Good

Coop- Sure you can beast this game and run rambo but the game really shines when everyone quits worrying about maxing kills, perking up, or being a super noob and you get a good set of team mates that rely on a mix of classes.  You will often hear people cry how hard this game is or can be and not playing coop is typically at the heart of that cry :D If you do get ahead on the leaderboards support your team with your extra dosh or buy and drop weps BOOM thats coop! Oh, and pubs aren't all that scary don't be afraid to play outside your circle of friends or clans.

reviewText:
Good +Easy to pick up or drop
+Progression
+Good classes
+Good enemy variety
+LOADS OF MONEY
+Guns
+Easter eggs, cross-game content (RO2 costumes, Portal maps)
+Modded Servers

Bad -All the voice acting in the base game is done by two people and it's terrible
-Fairly primitive graphics
-Uninspiring soundtrack

DLCA pretty healthy chunk of free DLC at frequent intervals and a variety of useful (dual-wielded flare pistols) and intentionally not so useful (gold-plated AK-47!) paid DLC is available.

Worth?I'd probably still get this game for $20 if the sequel wasn't about to hit.

ReviewKilling Floor isn't actually a Nazi Zombies clone. if you watch videos on how Nazi Zombies was made, the devs played a flash game called 'SAS Zombie Assault.' This is basically that game. It's a frantic skill-based grenade fest with terrible production values.

Rather than trying to look pretty, Tripwire did their best to make Killing Floor as good as possible for the money.  None of this 'vertical foregrip adds to stability on fully automatic but lol it's not the DLC edition and removes accuracy.' Nope. KF rewards you for investing inane amounts of time with awesome abilities and free weapons.

You know how some class based games just give you different abilities? Killing Floor actually makes some of the enemies fatally weak to certain classes and highly resistant to others. A good example is the 'Scrake,' some ♥♥♥♥er with a chainsaw that the 'Sharpshooter' can insta-kill with the crossbow, while being resistant to explosives lobbed by the demolitions guy. One of the really smart mechanics is they discount your class's weapons to make it easier to get into your given role. Eventually you get basic weapons for free!

Rather than try to limit you to a certain playstyle, Killing Floor is basically designed to reward you for playing like a skilled maniac. You think guns suck and fire is the only way? Well, maybe you'll change your mind if we give you a MAC-10 that fires flaming bullets! There's a flamethrower anyway in case you don't buy it.

They also try to release a free DLC with every purchaseable DLC you can also get, and to their credit, there are numerous new voiced characters available. They even saw a community-made weapons pack got super popular and made it an official community pack. That alone is enough for me to support the game, but it does help it's insanely fun and difficult - but not quite impossible, either.

reviewText: This is not your standard wave after wave zombie survival game with slow mindless beings coming after you. Nine types of ZED’s (name for these zombies, that aren’t actually zombies at all) with their own special traits, Seven classes to choose from with their own perk from damage reduction, faster reloads or bigger magazine sizes with their style of weapon or a free starting gun if you level up enough. All thrown on maps from open Mountain passes to tight corridors in the Bio labs that they come from means you got your work cut out, so grab some friend (the ones that can aim) and get stuck in. Ow, and once you think you have survived the waves there’s one last little surprise for you, seem like the Patriarch doesn’t like you killing his children, See you on the battlefield, if you survive.

reviewText:
Good +Easy to pick up or drop
+Progression
+Good classes
+Good enemy variety
+LOADS OF MONEY
+Guns
+Easter eggs, cross-game content (RO2 costumes, Portal maps)
+Modded Servers

Bad -All the voice acting in the base game is done by two people and it's terrible
-Fairly primitive graphics
-Uninspiring soundtrack

DLCA pretty healthy chunk of free DLC at frequent intervals and a variety of useful (dual-wielded flare pistols) and intentionally not so useful (gold-plated AK-47!) paid DLC is available.

Worth?I'd probably still get this game for $20 if the sequel wasn't about to hit.

ReviewKilling Floor isn't actually a Nazi Zombies clone. if you watch videos on how Nazi Zombies was made, the devs played a flash game called 'SAS Zombie Assault.' This is basically that game. It's a frantic skill-based grenade fest with terrible production values.

Rather than trying to look pretty, Tripwire did their best to make Killing Floor as good as possible for the money.  None of this 'vertical foregrip adds to stability on fully automatic but lol it's not the DLC edition and removes accuracy.' Nope. KF rewards you for investing inane amounts of time with awesome abilities and free weapons.

You know how some class based games just give you different abilities? Killing Floor actually makes some of the enemies fatally weak to certain classes and highly resistant to others. A good example is the 'Scrake,' some ♥♥♥♥er with a chainsaw that the 'Sharpshooter' can insta-kill with the crossbow, while being resistant to explosives lobbed by the demolitions guy. One of the really smart mechanics is they discount your class's weapons to make it easier to get into your given role. Eventually you get basic weapons for free!

Rather than try to limit you to a certain playstyle, Killing Floor is basically designed to reward you for playing like a skilled maniac. You think guns suck and fire is the only way? Well, maybe you'll change your mind if we give you a MAC-10 that fires flaming bullets! There's a flamethrower anyway in case you don't buy it.

They also try to release a free DLC with every purchaseable DLC you can also get, and to their credit, there are numerous new voiced characters available. They even saw a community-made weapons pack got super popular and made it an official community pack. That alone is enough for me to support the game, but it does help it's insanely fun and difficult - but not quite impossible, either.

reviewText:
I don't even know why I haven't reviewed this game yet, despite having (Probably) spent more time in it than any other game in my library. Really, what else is there to say than, it's fun! Not just the game is good but so it it's community, in most cases.

I recalled plenty of moments where after a wave I was short on cash, only to feel a smile tugging at my lips when a random person ran up to me and started throwing dosh at my face while yelling the game's characteristic “Loadsa moneh!”

There's beginner mode which is easy and can help any starting player learn the ropes, getting their first perk levels while chopping off specimen heads left and right, is there's one thing bad about it, is that from beginner to normal is such a huge jump, making the game suddenly feel rather, difficult for new players. It does however do well at making the players work together. Two people working as a team can wreak havoc in hard mode whereas six people that don't will only end up failing in normal. I like that.

Every match can last anywhere from 3 minutes (If you die early) to 45 minutes (On long games) and whether you win or not, you'll still most often know that you made some progress levelling towards your next perk level.

It will probably go on sale again this winter, and the monsters will all look their christmassy best again (They already do!) so if you have a bit of dosh. Get it, bring some friends, and get hunting!

Some protips.
- Dual Handcannons are objectively the best weapon in the game.
- The easiest difficulty is Hell on Earth, despite the scary name. If it is your first time playing look for the red skull emblem.
- There is no benefit to levelling your perks, and using off perk weapons is not only better it's advise.
- You should always attempt to 360 knife decap bloats, as any perk. Brownie points if Demolitionist.

Using these tips you can go far!

reviewText:
Killing floor is a wave based zombie shooter with 8 different types of zombies/mutants and a player limit of 6 or so (many more on modded servers though). Game play is basic you pick a perk (Demolitions (grenade launchers and my fav), Support (shotgun and welder), Sharpshooter (pistols and rifles), Berserker (Melee weapons), Pyro (flame based weapons), Medic (Obvious), Commando (Assault rifles). You can purchase weapons of any class at the end of a wave at a trader which is open for a variable amount of time based on settings. In addition to your weapons every class has a medic gun and a welder (both work only at melee range) but their effectiveness is based on your perk. You can weld certain doors and gates closed letting you hold off the horde that little while longer. Guns sound awesome, a decent variety for each class. You are limited by a weight limit for how many weapons you can carry though (not by slots). The base game has quite a few maps including a couple of objective maps as well as a few sandbox settings and difficulty levels.

The base game is quite fun for the first few weeks but starts to get samey/grindy which is why i HIGHLY recommend to play on a modded server. There is also a lot of things on the workshop page (especially modded maps) which i also recommend checking out too. The workshop is why i kept playing from 30 hours onward. The game also has holiday orientated events (Halloween redneck zombies, evil Santa)

Graphics are okay (game is a couple of years old) and it is very gory with no geo block :D. Which is why the demo class is so fun XD. Sounds are pretty good, guns feel nice (especially the 9mm). Maps vary from open, outdoors, corridors, small e.c.t so there is a lot of variety there. That about sums up KF, its simple but fun. I would recommend it (especially on sale), it also is still receiving updates. (Don't think i forgot anything).

reviewText:
About Game:
Killing Floor (abbreviated as KF) is a cooperative first-person shooter video game developed and published by Tripwire Interactive. It was originally released as an Unreal Tournament 2004 mod in 2005

Gameplay:
Killing Floor is a first person shooter, allowing each player to move through a 3D environment. Gameplay consists of two game types, in which the player fights waves of zombie-like specimens, with each wave becoming successively more difficult, until it concludes with a battle against a boss" specimen

column28: the Field Medic perk requires the player to heal a number of points to level up
column29: but this can also be done while playing any of the other perks.\n\nPlayers that die during a wave will drop their current weapon and re-enter the game at the start of the next wave
column30: as long as at least one squad member survives. If the entire squad is wiped out
column31: they will have to restart the game from the first round.\n\nEach game can be configured to alter the length and difficulty of the various waves. The number of creatures in the enemy waves are based on the number of players in the game
column32: increasing in numbers if more players join the game in progress. All but the weakest enemies have some special attack that can inflict significant damage on a player. A feature called "zed time" awards particularly gory kills

Plot:
The game takes place in London
column38: is contracted to conduct experiments of a military nature involving mass cloning and genetic manipulation. Something goes horribly wrong during the process of the experimentations
column39: and human subjects begin to exhibit grotesque mutations and disfigurement. They become increasingly hostile
column40: and eventually overrun the internal security forces of the corporation.\n\nHours later
column41: the first waves of the specimens break out onto the surface
column42: disrupting a peace protest outside the well-known military contractor. Despite the best efforts of local police
column43: the civilians are quickly overwhelmed and consumed by the seemingly endless supply of clones now streaming from the gaping maw of Horzine Biotech's headquarter. Having escaped their sterile prison
column44: the creatures began to fan out to neighboring areas
column45: devouring the helpless citizens of London while the Metropolitan Police bravely but fruitlessly attempt to stem the tide of mutated flesh now spreading across their city.\n\nDesperate to contain the outbreak from reaching overseas as planned by the now mutated and cybernetic-enhanced scientist Dr. Kevin Clamely (which is now the Patriarch)
column46: the British government quickly begins to organize ragtag teams of surviving British Army soldiers and Special Branch police officers to fight back against the hordes of mutated "specimens" now running amok throughout the capital and its outskirts. The player takes the role of a member of one of these teams as they partake in a variety of missions in and around the city of London.\n\nMy favorite and one of the best coop based multiplayer game ever! Make sure that you play with friends

reviewText:
Killing Floor foi, e ainda é, uma experiência que guardarei por muito tempo. É um jogo de estilo FPS / Gore, atendeu as espectativas dos fãns e ainda atenderá dos futuros jogadores.

Q.A

Q: Killing Floor é um jogo de Zumbi?
A: Não. De acordo com a história do Killing Floor, eles são frutos de alterações genéticas.

Q: Da onde sai tanto ZED?
A: Patriarch :p

Q: O jogo tem mods e mapas na Workshop?
A: Sim. Há vários servidores customizados com Mods, sendo um deles o servidor Sexta Bruta HARDCORE.

Q: Vale a pena comprar?
A: Por mim vale, mas se você estiver achando o preço um pouco salgado, espere uma promoção.

Q: Em uma partida comum, quantos jogadores podem ficar em uma mesma sala?
A: Em servidores normais, 6 pessoas ao total. No caso de servidores com mods, ja vi servidores com até 30 pessoas simultaneamente.

Q: Qual a sua nota para o jogo?
A: Nota 10/10

reviewText: Bloody and Brilliant!\n\nAfter putting a 1000 Hrs Straight on it, I can safely say that this is indeed my preferred and great personal favorite on Steam. Game can be challenging and unpredictable at times, loading and lobby searching can be tedious, and the steps to host your own lobby is not worth the effort and headaches. Other than that I cannot mislead you because many find this game Bloody and Brilliant. >:D

reviewText: Killing Floor is a co-operative survival game, but doesn't have you fight against hunger or sleep deprivation as much as it has you defend your limbs from getting eaten by various creeps. At your behalf is a trader who remains at the infested locations solely to sell you a wide variety of legal and illegal weapons to use against the walking horrors armed with their own arsenal of, including but not limited to, teeth, claws, fireball launchers, chainsaws and miniguns. One of the game's core mechanics is a sophisticated economy system, involving running around like a bloody idiot yelling 'Dosh!' while throwing money at eachother.\n\nIf you are educated in the arts of weapon and/or money handling, you need this game. If not, you still need this game.

reviewText: You never can predict who will survive an apocalypse.  It's an unlikely combination of headshot percentage, situational awareness, and an appropriate hold over one's sense of self-preservation.  A Berzerker can charge fearlessly,  but will likely succumb to friendly fire if too psyched up.  A Firebug will too often find his friends as flammable as the ZEDs.  Most Assaults can't hit the broadside of a barn.  A Support might find the confidence of a shotgun is falsely assured, and weld shut his only chance of escape.  A cool-headed Sharpshooter might find he didn't panic enough, stuck in a corner.  A Medic will learn too late he let too many friends die.  Damn you, Horizine.  You've condemned us all to hell.. well, not me.  I could stare down the gates of Hell with a bolt action rifle, and thanks to Killing Floor, laugh at all other minor cataclysms.  MONEY, MONEY, MONEY! The other survivors will look and dress exactly like me, a ninja in riot gear. Learn to love the endless loops of generic death metal. Insult specimens. Run faster with the knife. Aim for the head.  Let's get to the trader.

reviewText: Killing Floor tells the story of Booker T. DeWitt, a private detective hired to investigate the kidnapping of Dosh by an ancient race of sentient machines known as The Reapers". The "Reapers" live underground and use emergence holes to access the world above. Aided by his old friend Victor Sullivan they must retrieve an item known as the Cintamani Stone in order to fight an invasion by a terrifying parasitic alien horde known as The Flood.\nThe game Stars Bill Cosby as the voice of The Fleshpund and a musical score by Michael Buble and performances by the cast of smash hit broadway musical 'Cats'.\nKilling Floor is a quirky
date: indie romp with a fantastic performance from Ellen Page as Mr. Fosters love interest.\nI heartily recommend this game to anyone who loves 2d sidesrolling platformers"

reviewText:
Killing Floor is an intense RPG/FPS that can take minutes to get into but hundreds of hours to become proficient at.  The game offers 5 difficulties, the lower of which you can be comfortable playing alone but the higher difficulties demand exceptional teamwork in order to overcome the grisly odds.  Seven different perks that grow in power as you level them up to six times allow you to choose the type of destruction you wish to bring to the mutant freaks.

The combat includes anywhere from one to six players and the more people you have on your squad the larger the force and the bigger the healthpool of the opposition.  The menace you attempt to best with your buddies is as diverse as they are deadly.  Wave-based gameplay gradually introduces you to the specimens while giving you time to save up your dosh for spending at the games rather formidable armory.

While the game is four years old the developers still release brand new content for the game on a semi-regular basis, with seasonal updates that reskin the specimens you fight into hilariously creepy incarnations.  New characters, new weapons and new maps await even the veteran players every few months.

reviewText:
Right, where do I start?

Killing Floor is a Survival Co-op, wave based game that was originally a mod for Unreal Tournement 2004. The goal is to survive the waves by killing ♥♥♥♥. Killing ♥♥♥♥ earns money which then can be spent at the trader in-between waves for guns, ammo and armour.

The game revolves around a perk system, players can pick a perk that can be helpful (or detrimental) to the team. Each perk usually has positives and negatives to using them. For example, Beserkers get up close and personal to hack and slash specimen and can soak up bits of damage. The Field Medic keeps the team alive by healing them via syringe injections and have very durable armour so can soak up damage if needed. Firebugs are great at crowd control by setting groups of specimen on fire to deal damage overtime and to slow them down and so on. However the perk you choose is not set in stone, you can switch in-between waves during trader time and also it sometimes helps to have off-perk weapons in some cases.

The game is greatly optimized, it can play on most toasters with ease and comes with so many graphical options that even puts Twinnings teabag varieties to shame. The learning curve can be steep, I would advise playing on easy or normal difficulty to start with to get used to the mechanics. Most harder difficulty games (Suicidal and Hell On Earth) often require higher perk levels, practice makes perfect.

Perhaps the main thing that keeps me coming back to this game is the modders. Modded servers are a whole new ball game with the inclusion of content such as maps, perks, specimen and weapons. The amount of new content on some of them are so extreme that you may not want to ever go back to stock. You have been warned!!!!

With over 2.5k hours invested in the game so far, this is easily the game that I play the most and for a good reason.

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by looking at this FPS and thinking that because it looks a bit dated, it isn't very good. Yes, it is indeed a few years old now but it still holds up VERY well today, despite there being numerous offerings in the wave-based FPS shooter (such as Left 4 Dead).

This was one of my first purchases on Steam 3 years ago, and it was a gamble for me as it was on offer. It's also ended up being one of my most played games. It certainly has surprised me.

It previously won the annual award for best Unreal Engine mod, and you can quickly see why when you get into it. At first, you might be surprised that it's so simplistic in it's offering - you fight of a series of progressively harder waves of specimens" (don't say the "z" word!)
date: culminating in a boss battle. There's a fair choice of pretty well-designed maps too.\n\nHowever
recommended: this game is much more than the mere sum of it's parts. There's a good choice of weapons - in many games

voteText: but here they are not just clearly individual and well-balanced (so you can comfortably work with which ones suit your style)
helpfulPercent: they have real heft

votesTotal: sounding and feeling excellent. I'd go as far as to say these are probably one of the best examples of guns in a game - they are the real stars here.\n\nThe game's real unique point lies in it's class system - each option will give you bonuses to the applicable weapons for that class (example: a Firebug will do extra damage with flamethrowers). This variety really lends itself well when in co-operative multiplayer; get the right balance on your squad of teammates and you can be a unit of near-invincible mince-making machines
votesFunny: especially when those classes can earn experience to level up

reviewText:
Welcome to my review of Killing Floor. Now, I could go on and on with some boring review, but why do that when I can just be straight to the point?

This here is Killing Floor. This is a game where you, to great surprise, kill things. In fact, you kill a lot of things. To be honest, I hope you like killing things, because that's this game's primary feature!

Not entirely 100% positive what the things are? Don't worry, because we aren't either! Before you know it, you too, will be mindlessly firing the portable killing machine of your choice beside others who share your newly obtained urge to fire weapons at mutants without questioning the logic of why you're a military operative sent against mutants with nothing but a Beretta M9, a knife, a welding tool, and a healing injector that magically recharges over time!

What do you do? Simple! You kill things. Once you're done killing things, you get weapons from the money you got from killing things so you can kill more things and earn MORE money to get BETTER weapons to kill more things with, until you finally kill enough things to get to the big thing called the patriarch. By then, hopefully your squad of originally highly unprepared, lighthearted, talkative british soldiers will have killed enough things to get powerful enough weapons to stand a chance against this final mutant! What happens when you win, you ask? You do it all over again! Astonishing, correct?

How do you get weapons? Like any fully-unprepared squad of six brits would in an apocalypse! You trust a completely legitimate travelling mercenary who has no affiliation with the army, that conveniently manages to travel from shop to shop for absolutely no reason since it's all within the same small area, without ever having to fight any of the mutants you're facing! We should also note that she is the only living person in the game aside from your squad, so it's your job to make sure that you clean out these completely decimated areas so the people that don't live anymore can be free!

But killing things with portable killing machines is just not enough! The game uses a class system. Now, I could use the actual names, but who needs names to confuse people, when we're already throwing logic out the window?! Lets just use fancy, informative descriptions!

Our fabulous classes include:

Brits who shoot things with automatic weapons and can see invisible women.

Brits who heal people with the same automatic weapons they kill things with, while tanking damage like no one else ever could.

Brits who burn things.

Brits who blow things up.

Brits who blast things with shotguns and carry more than anyone else.

Brits who snipe enemies from afar and fail to realize pistols are actually powerful in this game.

And lastly, Brits who run really fast and use melee weapons to attack the enemies that are also primarily limited to melee attacks!


Should you play long enough to level a class up really far, the queen will smile upon your efforts and no longer send you in with just a Beretta M9 and a knife to fight with on the first wave - instead, she will provide you with a weapon for your class that is significantly more useful! In addition, levelling up causes the goddess of guns to bless your firearms that match your class with improved firepower! No, she doesn't give you new kinds of bullets, or modifications to the guns, they just magically obtain greater potential! It makes perfect sense if you don't think about it, and why would you?! Your thoughts should be focused on killing mutants, you bloody fool!


But make no mistake - this is NOT a first person shooter! No, this is in fact a killing simulator. That's right, a killing simulator! You aren't just shooting these mutants, it's up to you whether or not you take limbs off their torsos, blast their heads off, decapitate them, burn them alive, or blast them to little bits! Be creative with how you kill mutants, just don't give them the opportunity to be creative as well!

Need more guns? Of course you do! That's why there's three weapon pack DLCs! Don't like DLCs? No problem! Turn to modding, and make Killing Floor's battles into an even bigger massacre than they already are!

So what are you waiting for? Throw away your logic, bring your friends, lose your social life, and get to slaughtering mutants over and over, because who needs reasons anyway?!

reviewText:
It's challenging and rewarding and loads more fun than KF2.

There is a wide range of weapons to use on all perks which allows for various strategies and playstyles. And after you've become tired of the base game weapons, you can purchase more weapons via dlc packs. And the dlc weapons are either reskins or whole new weapons, so it adds even more variety. I've been playing with just the base game weapons, if I want to use the dlc weapons, I can trade them off someone and paying them dosh for it (in-game currency). So, no real money is really needed to use dlc weapons as long as you play with someone who has them!

Zeds are interesting and challenging, it will take practice to understand various strategies on killing them. It's not always as simple as shooting them, some bigger zeds might require specific strategies to kill effectively. And if you get bored of base game zeds, you can play against 3 reskinned themes including halloween, hillbilly, and christmas zeds. If that's not enough, there are custom mod servers out there with brand new zeds and weapons. You need only join these custom servers and the game will do the rest for you (downloading them and such).

The music is metal and it's nice to listen to. Personally, I turn the music off when I play because it's easier to hear zeds behind you without screaming metal blasting in the background.

Pros:Lots of weapons
Challenging enemies
Fun teamplay elements
Money management
Chat commands are often funny or informative (i.e. Insult Players)
You can get dlc weapons off other players (no purchase of dlc required)
No sprint (some people say this is a con but I think it's a pro because it adds desperation and challenge to a given situation. I think sprint in KF2 ruined the experience.)
High recoil on weapons
Cons:Metal music can be distracting if you're not watching your back
Lobby ads can get really annoying (there are mods to change/disable them)
Menu buttons are sometimes a little wonky (requiring a second or third click)
Neutral:Dark filter makes colours seem dull but it increases the gritty atmosphere
Trader dialogue gets on my nerves sometimes (personal preference so not a con)
Modding sounds or music will change it for singleplayer but not online
Only one boss but his diologue is funny
Some strategies are kind of cheesy but fun to do yourself (i.e. blowing up boss with a few dozen demo charges)
I can't think of anything else to add but it's definately a golden title of a game, I highly recommend it. 10/10

reviewText:
Zombies are enjoying a bit of a renaissance lately (which is somewhat ironic considering their undead nature). The shambling hordes can be found in everything from action titles such as Dead Rising to tower defense games such as Plants Vs. Zombies, and the undisputed current king of zombie titles, Left 4 Dead. Capitalizing on this recent trend, Tripwire Interactive has released Killing Floor, a downloadable title over Steam that initially was released as an Unreal Tournament 2004 mod four years ago. While it's still held down by a number of bugs, Killing Floor is an enjoyable alternative for those players that have exhausted their time with Left 4 Dead and are looking for something new.

The story behind Killing Floor takes place in London, where the metropolitan city has been devastated by a large outbreak of the undead eating and maiming everyone in sight. In reality, these creatures aren't zombies at all; instead, they are specimens cloned by a biotech firm. Naturally, they managed to escape and decimate the population. Thanks to the brutality of the attack, very few people are left within London or its surrounding area. You happen to be one of them. As one of up to six survivors (two policemen and four soldiers), it's up to you to put an end to the threat by destroying all of the creatures that you come across. The characters themselves have their own individual bios, including a constable with a knack for police brutality and a soldier who collects fingers of the creatures he kills. The individual details aren't really important since they don't help provide any additional skills or abilities to the character; they just give a mild insight to who these people were before hell broke loose.

Regardless of which character you choose, players are also tasked with selecting one of six specific character perks. Akin to establishing a class system within the game, the perks give you a number of effects that are imparted to your character to help them survive each battle. For example, Field Medics are better at healing characters and defending themselves, Support Specialists can carry more weaponry and do significant damage with shotguns, and Sharpshooters do extra damage with headshots while experiencing limited recoil. Initially, character perks start at level 0, and all have specific requirements that have to be fulfilled before a bonus can be imparted to the character. So if you want to improve your Firebug skills to do extra damage with a Flamethrower, you're going to have to cause 25,000 points of damage with the weapon.

You can improve any perk whether you've selected it or not by simply choosing to use a particular weapon, which is useful because you don't have to constantly switch back and forth between perks. For instance, you can be a Commando (which focuses on using the Bullpup machine gun) and still improve your Berserker rating by pulling out a knife and stabbing opponents. Since the requirements to reach each levels quickly starts to grow until you get to the level 5 max, you'll be able to play for quite a long time before you max out the advantages, which will earn you a specific weapon when spawning into a round. The only downside is that you might not choose to explore all of the perks once you find a role that you particularly like thanks to this system, so you may never care to master the perks.

Once you've chosen, you're sent into the middle of a map with a basic assortment of weapons and gear. You begin with a knife, a 9 millimeter pistol with about eight clips of ammo and three grenades to help you defend yourself. Equipment wise, you're packing a flashlight with a regenerating battery as well as a hypodermic syringe which can be used to heal any damage that you or your friends may take. You'll need to wait a few seconds before you can use it again, but considering that you won't find any health packs or bandages anywhere during your battles, you'll come to rely on this item over and over again. The last bit of gear is the welding torch, which can be used to seal doors to help funnel enemies where you want them to go so you're not completely surrounded. It can also be used to break seals in case you've attempted to create a safe room and your plans fall apart.

This will happen frequently under the onslaught of hordes of creatures that assault you and your teammates in a series of intensifying waves. Initially, you might face off against a set of mindless creatures known as Clots, who grab onto you and attempt to bite you to death. Shortly afterwards, you'll run into a larger variety of beasts, including freaks with large scythes or chainsaws on their arms, spider-like monsters, and large muscular beasts that smash through anything in their path. Every monster that you kill provides you with cash; between rounds you have a minute to track down a trader that sets up shop to sell you weapons and gear. You're not able to pick up every weapon you want, of course, your character is restricted by a set weight limit that forces you to pick and choose what gear you'll take with you in the next round.

reviewText:
Time for a re-review, since I never gave it a proper one.

*Sees Patriarch*
*Insult Specimen*

Killing Floor is a HARDCORE Post Apocalyptic Co-op Survival game, or in other words, Post Apocalyptic life simulator in Great Britain where you have to kill zeds to earn Do$h which you use to buy weapons to kill even more zeds.

Emphasis on 'HARDCORE'. It is easily one of the most difficult, hardcore games I've ever played. It makes Payday: The Heist (another co-op game at which I'm really good at) look easy in comparison. Hell I like playing games on the hardest difficulties, but on this game, even Hard difficulty on certain maps (which is below Suicidal and Hell On Earth) can be pretty hard. Or maybe I'm just not good enough.

Features 2 different game modes, standard wave-based Survival mode and Objective mode, 7 different classes, a large variety of enemy zeds, each with their own strenghts and weaknesses, a ton of weapons, Instrumental Industrial Heavy Metal, along with some Electronic music, which are both pretty damn nice.

Weapons are all really fun to use. Impactful, great sounds, manual recoil control, all make for terrific gunplay.

The game can be described as somewhat boring, yet fun at the same time (at least on the standard Survival mode). One 10 wave game can last up to 50 minutes or more. On most maps you either spend the entire match camping one certain spot, or kiting around the map with a certain strategy. To add to the tension, after killing everything in a wave, you only have 60 seconds to get to the trader, resupply, and regroup. If you kill all the specimens while being far away from the trader, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. Killing everything as fast as possible while kiting can trigger far too many enemy spawns to spawn in the direction you're going, which can cause the death of your team (or yourself while playing Solo!)

Now let's get to the bad parts. The game suffers from a half broken server browser, in the sense that it is REALLY REALLY slow. The solution to that is to Alt-Tab into the desktop for several seconds and then Alt-Tab back into the game to get the complete server list. There's arguably somewhat better weapons behind community weapon pack DLCs. Then there's the wonky head hitboxes, which can make going for headshots with certain projectile based weapons very unreliable, preventing them from reaching their maximum potential.

For any aspiring Firebug player such as myself, I give you this important piece of advice. Do not aim for the head with the Husk Fireball Launcher! The flaming missiles will either register as body shots, or simply light the specimen on fire without dealing any impact damage. It is simply not worth it. No amount of practice will help you with the hitbox issues. Aim for center mass or the neck area and hope you get lucky. It will still deal a massive amount of damage.

Unless you're level 5 or 6 on a class (you spawn with a class weapon at level 5), joining games that are past wave 2, 3 or so is not recommended, and even then, I wouldn't do it on higher difficulties. You won't have the gear to face the extra specimens, or money to upgrade. You might end up hurting the team you join. This is where the leveling system works against the player. Also, the Commando has the worst requirements for leveling up of all the classes. For this class alone, I suggest using leveling maps for killing Stalkers.

And, trying to play on the more difficult, less played maps can be difficult. The server list is either populated by overplayed easy maps, or custom ones. BioticsLab (which is a base game map) is ♥♥♥♥ing boring and easy as hell, and trying to get a game on Clandestine or Hell can be difficult. If you do find a server playing on a specific map, it might be already past wave 3 or more, and joining it then is just suicidal.

Despite all these issues, I guess I still recommend the game.
